{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2017 YE|5}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = {{mp|2017 YE|5}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = File:Radar images of binary asteroid 2017 YE5 (2018-06-23, -25).gif | image_size = 250 | caption = Radar images of [[binary asteroid]] {{mp|2017 YE|5}}: top, [[Goldstone Solar System Radar|Goldstone]]; bottom, [[Arecibo Observatory|Arecibo]] transmitting with [[Green Bank Telescope|Green Bank]] receiving | discovery_ref =   | discovered = December 21, 2017 | discoverer = [[Claudine Rinner|C. Rinner]]
[[Michel Ory|M. Ory]]
B. Zouhair | discovery_site = Oukaimeden Obs. {{Obscode|J43}}
Cadi Ayyad University Obs. | mpc_name = {{mp|2017 YE|5}} | alt_names = | adjectives = | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Binary asteroid|Binary]] [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]] | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 23 March 2018 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458200.5) | uncertainty = 4 | observation_arc = 0.57 yr (210 days) | aphelion = 4.82 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.8171 AU | semimajor = 2.82 AU | eccentricity = 0.7102 | period = 4.74 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (1730 days) | mean_anomaly = 349.0° | mean_motion = 0.2081°/day | inclination = 6.21° | asc_node = 103.96° | arg_peri = 110.77° | moid = 0.0206 AU | mean_diameter = {{val|0.9|ul=km}} {{small|(for each body)}} | mass = | density = | rotation = | albedo = | spectral_type = | magnitude = | abs_magnitude = 19.3 }} '''{{mp|2017 YE|5}}''' is the provisional name for a sub-kilometer, binary [[Near-Earth asteroid|near Earth]] ([[Apollo asteroid|Apollo]]) [[asteroid]] that passed within 16 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|lunar distances]], {{convert|6|e6km}}, from Earth on 21 June 2018,{{cite web|url=https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2017+YE5|title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser|first=Alan|last=Chamberlin|website=ssd.jpl.nasa.gov}} which will be the closest approach for the next 170 years. Each member of the binary has approximately equal mass, and is about {{convert|0.9|km}} in diameter. The orbital period is {{convert|4.74|year|days}}, and the bodies revolve around their common [[barycenter]] with a period of {{val|20|-|24|u=hours}}. == Discovery == The [[binary asteroid]] was discovered in December 2017 by amateur astronomers [[Claudine Rinner]]{{cite web | url= http://www.planetary.org/blogs/jason-davis/shoemaker-winners-2017-ye5.html | title= Planetary Society asteroid hunters help find rare type of double asteroid | last= Davis | first= Jason | date= 2018-07-24 | website= www.planetary.org/blogs | publisher= [[The Planetary Society]] | access-date= 2018-07-24}} and [[Michel Ory]] with observations provided by [[Cadi Ayyad University]]'s Morocco Oukaimeden Sky Survey Telescope{{cite web | url= http://moss-observatory.org/ | title= Morocco Oukaïmeden Sky Survey | date= 2018-03-13 | website= moss-observatory.org/ | publisher= [[Jura Observatory|Société jurassienne d'astronomie]] | access-date = 2018-07-13}}{{cite web | url= http://www.planetary.org/blogs/jason-davis/planetary-defense-in-morocco.html | title= Planetary Defense in the Moroccan Mountains | last= Davis | first= Jason | date= 2018-07-03 | website= www.planetary.org/blogs | publisher= [[The Planetary Society]] | access-date= 2018-07-28}}{{cite web | url= http://www.planetary.org/multimedia/planetary-radio/show/2018/0718-2018-spahr-ory-shoemaker-neo.html | title= An African Observatory Hunts Killer Asteroids | last1= Kaplan | first1= Mat | author1-link= Mat Kaplan|last2= Ory | first2= Michel | author2-link= Michel Ory|date= 2018-07-03 | website= www.planetary.org/multimedia/planetary-radio | publisher= [[The Planetary Society]] | access-date= 2018-07-28}} (observatory director, Benkhaldoun Zouhair), and the [[Mount Lemmon Survey]].{{cite web |title=Goldstone Radar Observations Planning: 2017 YE5, 1996 AW1, 2010 NY65, and 2018 LK |url=https://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/asteroids/2010NY65_2018/2010NY65_planning.2018.html |website=echo.jpl.nasa.gov |accessdate=18 July 2018}} The asteroid was determined to be a near-equal mass binary asteroid using [[bistatic radar]] measurements from [[Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex|Goldstone]], [[Arecibo Observatory]] and the [[Green Bank Observatory]].{{cite web |last1=Cofield |first1=Calla |last2=Wendel |first2=JoAnna |title=Observatories Team Up to Reveal Rare Double Asteroid |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7187 |date=12 July 2018 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=12 July 2018 }}{{cite web |last1=Dvorsky |first1=George |title=Newly Discovered 'Asteroid' Is Far Freakier Than Astronomers Expected |url=https://gizmodo.com/newly-discovered-asteroid-is-far-freakier-than-astronom-1827572715 |website=Gizmodo |accessdate=18 July 2018 |date=13 July 2018}} [[File:PIA22559.gif|thumb|center|400px|
Radar image of asteroid {{mp|2017 YE|5}} binary.
]] [[File:PIA22560-Asteroid-2017-YE5-Orbit-20180712.gif|thumb|center|400px|
Asteroid {{mp|2017 YE|5}} trajectory through the solar system (animated).
]] == References== {{reflist}} == External links== * [http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/astro/astmoons/am2017ye5.html 2017 YE5], Asteroids with Satellites Database, Johnston's Archive * {{NeoDys|2017YE5}} * {{JPL small body|id=3795078}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{2018 in space}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2017 YE5}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Binary asteroids|*]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2018]] {{asteroid-stub}}

Bus|Schelte J. "Bobby" Bus]] | discovery_site = [[Siding Spring Observatory|Siding Spring Obs.]] | mpc_name = (3122) Florence | alt_names = {{mp|1981 ET|3}}{{·}}{{mp|1983 CN|1}} | pronounced = | named_after = [[Florence Nightingale]] 
{{small|(English nurse)}} | mp_category = [[Amor asteroid|Amor]]{{·}}[[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous object|PHA]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = 38.52 yr (14,069 days) | aphelion = 2.5180 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 1.0203 AU | semimajor = 1.7691 AU | eccentricity = 0.4233 | period = 2.35 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (859 days) | mean_anomaly = 351.44[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.4189|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 22.151° | asc_node = 336.10° | arg_peri = 27.847° | satellites = 2 | moid = 0.0443 AU{{·}}17.3 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]] | mean_diameter = {{val|4.010|1.237}} km

{{val|0.21|0.20}}
{{val|0.231|0.049}}
{{val|0.258|0.199}} | spectral_type = [[SMASS classification|SMASS]] {{=}} [[S-type asteroid|S]] {{·}}Sq  | abs_magnitude = {{val|13.87|0.1}} {{small|(R)}}{{efn|name=LCDB-Pravec-2002/2003}}{{·}}14.0{{·}}{{val|14.04|0.1}} {{small|(R)}}{{efn|name=LCDB-Pravec-2002/2003}}{{·}}14.1{{·}}{{val|14.515|0.11}}{{·}}{{val|14.65|0.11}}{{·}}{{val|14.65|0.3}} }} '''3122 Florence''' is a stony [[Trinary asteroid|trinary]] [[asteroid]] of the [[Amor asteroid|Amor]] group. It is classified as a [[near-Earth object]] and [[potentially hazardous asteroid]]. It measures approximately 5 kilometers in [[diameter]]. It orbits the Sun at a distance of 1.0–2.5 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 2 years and 4 months (859 days); the orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.42 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 22[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. Florence has [[#Moons|two moons]]. Florence was discovered on 2 March 1981 by American astronomer [[Schelte J. Bus|Schelte J. "Bobby" Bus]] at [[Siding Spring Observatory]]. Its provisional designation was {{mp|1981 ET|3}}. It was named in honor of [[Florence Nightingale]], the founder of modern nursing; the naming citation was published on 6 April, 1993 ({{small|[[Minor Planet Center#Publications|M.P.C.]] 21955}}). Florence is classified as a [[potentially hazardous object]] because its [[minimum orbit intersection distance]] {{nowrap|(''MOID'' ≤ 0.05 AU)}} indicates that it has the potential to make close approaches to the Earth, and because measurements of its [[absolute magnitude]] {{nowrap|(''H'' ≤ 22)}} suggest that it is large enough to create serious damage were it to impact.{{cite web|url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/neo/groups.html |title=NEO Groups |series=Near Earth Object Program |publisher=NASA |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161102020040/http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/neo/groups.html |archivedate=November 2, 2016 |deadurl=yes }} == Moons == [[File:3122 Florence with moons.jpg|thumb|left|[[Trinary asteroid]]: ''Florence'' with its two [[Minor-planet moon|satellites]]]] Radar observations during the 2017 flyby have shown that Florence has two moons. The inner of the two moons is estimated to have a diameter of 180 to 240 meters, the outer moon is between 300 and 360 meters across. Each moon is somewhat elongated, and both are [[tidal locking|tidally locked]] to the main body. They probably formed as loose material spun away from the main body as its rotation accelerated due to the [[YORP effect]]. The inner moon's period orbiting Florence appears to be approximately 7 hours, while the outer moon completes a revolution in about 21 to 23 hours. The inner moon of Florence has the shortest orbital period of any of the moons of the 60 near-Earth asteroids known to have moons. Florence is only the third known trinary asteroid in the near-Earth asteroid population, after [[(153591) 2001 SN263|{{mp|(153591) 2001 SN|3}}]] and [[(136617) 1994 CC|{{mp|(136617) 1994 CC}}]]. == 2017 close approach == {{As of | 2017 | alt=On 1 September 2017, Florence passed}} {{convert|0.047237|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth, approximately eighteen times the average distance of the Moon. As seen from Earth, it brightened to [[apparent magnitude]] 8.5, and was visible in small telescopes for several nights as it moves south to north through the constellations [[Piscis Austrinus]], [[Capricornus]], [[Aquarius (constellation)|Aquarius]], and [[Delphinus]]. This was the asteroid's closest approach since 1890 and the closest until after 2500.{{cite news|title=Nasa says big asteroid to pass safely by Earth on 1 September|url=http://www.livemint.com/Science/0Far3fmQLS4Bq6kUXKrMjM/Nasa-says-big-asteroid-to-pass-safely-by-Earth-on-1-Septembe.html|agency=Livemint|date=2017-08-18|author=PTI}}{{cite web|url=http://www.skyandtelescope.com/observing/see-asteroid-florence-fly-by-earth-this-week/|title=Asteroid Florence Pays Earth a Visit – Sky & Telescope|date=30 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=1 September 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://astrobob.areavoices.com/2017/08/30/see-florence-one-of-largest-near-earth-asteroids-zip-by-earth/|title=See Florence, One Of The Largest Near-Earth Asteroids, Zip By Earth|date=30 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=1 September 2017}} Its previous flyby was on August 29, 1930, at a distance of 0.05239 AU and the next one will be on September 2, 2057, at 0.049952 AU.{{cite web|url=https://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/asteroids/Florence/Florence_planning.html |title=Goldstone Radar Observations Planning: Asteroid 3122 Florence and 2001 QL142| publisher=NASA |date= 29 August 2017}} File:3122Florence (1981 ET3).gif|Animation: 2017-08-30 21:48:46 to 22:53:00 UTC File:Florence3122spon.jpg|3122 Florence passing the Earth in 2017 File:3122 Florence 2017 flyby3.png|Orbit of Florence File:3122 Florence 2017 flyby.png|Daily motion of 3122 Florence as seen from earth near 1 September 2017 flyby. === Radar imagery === During the flyby, scientists studied Florence using the [[Arecibo Observatory]] and the [[Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex]], and discovered that it has two moons.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AreciboRadar/status/903830614796894208 | title = Arecibo announces two moons (September 2nd) | date=2 September 2017| publisher=Twitter}} ; Goldstone Radar Florence.aug29.collage.5runs.p5usec.7.7Hz.jpg|Aug 29 Florence Goldstone September 1.gif|Sep 1 ; Arecibo Radar Florence Arecibo September 2.gif|Sep 2 Florence Arecibo September 2 (high-res).gif|Sep 2{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AreciboRadar/status/903846455970078721 | title = Arecibo imagery from September 2nd (5x higher resolution) | date=2 September 2017| publisher=Twitter}} Florence Arecibo September 3.gif|Sep 3{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AreciboRadar/status/904216481541615616 | title = Arecibo reveals surface features of 3122 Florence | date=3 September 2017| publisher=Twitter}} Florence Arecibo September 4.gif|Sep 4{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AreciboRadar/status/904570579168178177 | title = One full rotation of 3122 Florence, as seen from Arecibo | date=4 September 2017| publisher=Twitter}} Florence Arecibo September 5.gif|Sep 5{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AreciboRadar/status/904939585561661440 | title = Last images of 3122 Florence from Arecibo | date=5 September 2017| publisher=Twitter}} == Notes == {{notelist|refs= {{efn|name=LCDB-Pravec-2002/2003|1=Pravec (2002/2003) web: rotation period {{val|2.3581|0.0001}} hours with a brightness amplitude of {{val|0.15}} and 0.18 mag, respectively. Witt]] | discovery_site = [[IAU code#537|Berlin Urania Obs.]] | mpc_name = (433) Eros | alt_names = 1898 DQ{{·}}1956 PC | adjectives = Erotian | pronounced = | named_after = [[Eros]] {{small|([[Greek mythology]])}} | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Amor asteroid|Amor]] (I)
[[Mars-crosser]] | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 0 | observation_arc = 53.89 yr (19,683 days) | aphelion = 1.7825 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 1.1334 AU | semimajor = 1.4579 AU | eccentricity = 0.2226 | period = 1.76 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (643 days) | mean_anomaly = 71.280[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.5599|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 10.828° | asc_node = 304.32° | arg_peri = 178.82° | moid = 0.1505 AU{{·}}58.6 [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|LD]] | dimensions = {{val|16.84|0.06}} km {{small|(mean diameter)}}
{{small|34.4 × 11.2 × 11.2}} km | mass = (6.687±0.003){{e|15}} kg | density = {{val|2.67|0.03}} g/cm³ | rotation = 5.270 [[hour|h]] | albedo = {{val|0.25|0.06}} | spectral_type = [[S-type asteroid|S]] {{small|([[Tholen classification|Tholen]])}}, [[S-type asteroid|S]] {{small|([[SMASS classification|SMASS]])}}
[[Asteroid color indices|B–V]] = 0.921
[[Asteroid color indices|U–B]] = 0.531 | magnitude = 7.0–15 | abs_magnitude = 11.16 }} '''Eros''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɪər|ɒ|s}} {{respell|EER|os}}; [[minor planet designation]]: '''433 Eros'''), provisional designation {{mp|1898 DQ}}, is a stony and elongated [[asteroid]] of the [[Amor asteroid|Amor group]] and the first discovered and second-largest [[near-Earth object]] with a mean-diameter of approximately 16.8 kilometers. [[List of minor planets visited by spacecraft|Visited]] by the [[NEAR Shoemaker]] space probe in 1998, it became the first asteroid ever studied from orbit. The eccentric asteroid was discovered by German astronomer [[Carl Gustav Witt]] at the [[IAU code#537|Berlin Urania Observatory]] on 13 August 1898, and later named after [[Eros]], a god from [[Greek mythology]]. == History == === Discovery === Eros was discovered on 13 August 1898, by [[Carl Gustav Witt]] at [[IAU code#537|Berlin Urania Observatory]] and [[Auguste Charlois]] at [[Nice Observatory]]. Witt was taking a 2-hour exposure of [[Beta Aquarii]] to secure astrometric positions of asteroid [[185 Eunike]]. === Later studies === During the opposition of 1900–1901, a worldwide program was launched to make [[parallax]] measurements of Eros to determine the [[solar parallax]] (or distance to the Sun), with the results published in 1910 by [[Arthur Hinks]] of [[Cambridge]]. A similar program was then carried out, during a closer approach, in 1930–1931 by [[Harold Spencer Jones]]. The value of the [[Astronomical Unit]] (roughly the Earth-Sun distance) obtained by this program was considered definitive until 1968, when [[radar]] and [[dynamical parallax]] methods started producing more precise measurements. Eros was the first asteroid detected by the [[Arecibo Observatory]]'s radar system. Eros was one of the first asteroids visited by a spacecraft, the first one orbited, and the first one soft-landed on. [[NASA]] spacecraft [[NEAR Shoemaker]] entered orbit around Eros in 2000, and landed in 2001. === Mars-crosser === Eros is a [[Mars-crosser asteroid]], the first known to come within the orbit of [[Mars]]. Objects in such an orbit can remain there for only a few hundred million years before the orbit is [[Perturbation (astronomy)|perturbed]] by gravitational interactions. Dynamical integrations suggest that Eros may evolve into an [[Earth-crosser asteroid|Earth-crosser]] within as short an interval as two million years, and has a roughly 50% chance of doing so over a time scale of 108–109 years. It is a potential Earth [[Impact event|impactor]], about five times larger than the impactor that created [[Chicxulub crater]] and led to the [[Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event|extinction of the dinosaurs]].{{efn|name="ratio"}} === Name === Eros is named after the [[Greek mythology|Greek god]] of [[love]], [[Eros (god)|Erōs]]. It is pronounced {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɪər|ɒ|s}} {{respell|EER|os}} or sometimes {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ɛr|ɒ|s}} {{respell|ERR|os}}. The rarely used adjectival form of the name is ''Erotian'' {{IPAc-en|ᵻ|ˈ|r|oʊ|ʃ|ən}}. Eros is also the first masculine name for an asteroid.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/17301161|title=The asteroids|last=1920-1992.|first=Asimov, Isaac,|date=1988|publisher=G. Stevens Pub|isbn=1555323782|edition=A Gareth Stevens children's books|location=Milwaukee|oclc=17301161}} == ''NEAR Shoemaker'' == [[File:Animation of NEAR Shoemaker trajectory.gif|275px|thumb|right|Animation of NEAR Shoemaker trajectory from May 31, 1996 to February 12, 2001.
{{Font color|white|magenta|NEAR Shoemaker}}; {{Font color|white|lime| 433 Eros}}; {{Font color|white|royalblue|Earth}}; {{legend2|Cyan|[[253 Mathilde]] }}; {{Font color||yellow|Sun;}}]] [[File:Animation of NEAR Shoemaker trajectory around 433 Eros.gif |275px|thumb |right |Animation of [[NEAR Shoemaker]]{{'s}} trajectory around 433 Eros from April 1, 2000 to February 12, 2001
{{legend2|magenta| [[NEAR Shoemaker]]}}{{·}}{{legend2| Lime|433 Eros}}]] The [[NEAR Shoemaker]] probe visited Eros twice, first with a 1998 [[Planetary flyby|flyby]], and then by orbiting it in 2000 when it extensively photographed its surface. On February 12, 2001, at the end of its mission, it landed on the asteroid's surface using its maneuvering jets. == Physical characteristics == [[Surface gravity]] depends on the distance from a spot on the surface to the center of a body's mass. Eros's surface gravity varies greatly because Eros is not a sphere but an elongated peanut-shaped (or potato- or shoe-shaped) object. The daytime temperature on Eros can reach about {{convert|100|C|K}} at [[perihelion]]. Nighttime measurements fall near {{convert|-150|C|K}}. Eros's density is 2.67 [[Gram per cubic centimetre|g/cm3]], about the same as the density of Earth's crust. It rotates once every 5.27 hours. NEAR scientists have found that most of the larger rocks strewn across Eros were ejected from a single [[impact crater|crater]] in an impact approximately 1 billion years ago.{{cite journal|last1=Thomas|first1=P. C.|last2=Veverka|first2=J.|last3=Robinson|first3=M. S.|last4=Murchie |first4=S.| title =Shoemaker crater as the source of most ejecta blocks on the asteroid 433 Eros|journal=Nature |volume=413 |issue=6854|date=2001-09-27 |pages=394–396|issn=0028-0836|doi=10.1038/35096513|bibcode = 2001Natur.413..394T |pmid=11574880}} (The crater involved was proposed to be named "Shoemaker", but is not recognized as such by the [[International Astronomical Union]] (IAU), and has been formally designated Charlois Regio.) This event may also be responsible for the 40 percent of the Erotian surface that is devoid of craters smaller than 0.5 kilometers across. It was originally thought that the debris thrown up by the collision filled in the smaller craters. An analysis of crater densities over the surface indicates that the areas with lower crater density are within 9 kilometers of the impact point. Some of the lower density areas were found on the opposite side of the asteroid but still within 9 kilometers. It is theorized that [[seismic]] shockwaves propagated through the asteroid, shaking smaller craters into rubble. Since Eros is irregularly shaped, parts of the surface antipodal to the point of impact can be within 9 kilometres of the impact point (measured in a straight line through the asteroid) even though some intervening parts of the surface are more than 9 kilometres away in straight-line distance. A suitable analogy would be the distance from the top centre of a bun to the bottom centre as compared to the distance from the top centre to a point on the bun's circumference: top-to-bottom is a longer distance than top-to-periphery when measured along the surface but shorter than it in direct straight-line terms. Compression from the same impact is believed to have created the [[thrust fault]] Hinks Dorsum. Data from the Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous spacecraft collected on Eros in December 1998 suggests that it could contain 20,000 billion kilograms of aluminum and similar amounts of metals that are rare on Earth, such as gold and platinum.{{cite web|title=Gold rush in space?|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/sci/tech/401227.stm|website=BBC News|accessdate=13 December 2014}} == Visibility from Earth == [[File:Eros_path_2012.png|thumb|Path in sky during opposition 2011/2012]] On January 31, 2012, Eros passed Earth at {{convert|0.17867|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}}, about 70 times the [[Lunar distance (astronomy)|distance to the Moon]], with a [[apparent magnitude|visual magnitude]] of +8.1. During rare oppositions, every 81 years, such as in 1975 and 2056, Eros can reach a magnitude of +7.0, which is brighter than [[Neptune#Observation|Neptune]] and brighter than any [[main-belt asteroid]] except [[1 Ceres]], [[4 Vesta#Visibility|4 Vesta]] and, rarely, [[2 Pallas#Characteristics|2 Pallas]] and [[7 Iris]]. Under this condition, the asteroid actually appears to stop, but unlike the normal condition for a body in heliocentric conjunction with Earth, its [[Apparent retrograde motion|retrograde]] motion is very small. For example, in January and February 2137, it moves retrograde only 34 minutes in right ascension. {{clear}} == Gallery == File:Eros rotation Dec. 3-4 2000.gif|Animation of the rotation of Eros File:433eros.jpg|View from one end of Eros across the gouge on its side towards the opposite end File:433 Eros first look.jpg|At {{convert|abbr=on|4.8|km|mi|1}} across, the crater Psyche is Eros's second largest File:Erosregolith.jpg|[[Regolith]] of Eros, seen during NEAR's descent; area shown is about 12 meters (40 feet) across File:Eros May 7 2013.PNG|Orbital diagram of Eros with locations on May 7, 2013 File:Eros orbit 2018.png|Orbital diagram of Eros with locations on January 1, 2018 File:Eros, Vesta and Ceres size comparison.jpg|Size comparison of [[4 Vesta|Vesta]], [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]] and Eros File:PIA02475 Eros' Bland Butterscotch Colors.jpg|Six different views of Eros in approximate natural color from [[NEAR-Shoemaker]] in February 2000 {{clear}} == See also == * [[Asteroids in fiction#Eros|Eros in fiction]] * [[List of geological features on 433 Eros]] == Notes == {{notelist|refs= {{efn|name="ratio"|1=Ratio of mean diameters is 16.84 km/~10 km; the volume ratio is approximately 4.8 (cubed value).}} {{efn|name="extended-description"|1=A composite image of the north polar region, with the [[impact crater|craters]] Psyche above and Himeros below. The long ridge Hinks Dorsum, believed to be a [[thrust fault]], can be seen snaking diagonally between them. The smaller crater in the foreground is Narcissus ([http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2011GeoRL..38.2202W Watters, 2011])}} }} == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |type = 2017-06-04 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 433 Eros (1898 DQ) |url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2000433 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 16 August 2017}} {{cite book |title = Dictionary of Minor Planet Names – (433) Eros |last = Schmadel | first = Lutz D. |publisher = [[Springer Berlin Heidelberg]] |page = 50 |date = 2007 |url = https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-540-29925-7_434 |isbn = 978-3-540-00238-3 |accessdate = 16 August 2017}} {{cite web |date=2008 |title=Recent Asteroid Mass Determinations |publisher=Personal Website |author=Jim Baer |url=http://home.earthlink.net/~jimbaer1/astmass.txt |accessdate=2008-12-11}} {{cite web |title=NEODys (433) Eros Ephemerides for 2137 |publisher=Department of Mathematics, University of Pisa, Italy |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=433&oc=500&y0=2137&m0=1&d0=24&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2137&m1=1&d1=25&h1=0&mi1=0&ti=1.0&tiu=days |accessdate=2010-06-27}} {{Cite journal | last = Michel | first = Patrick | last2 = Farinella |first2=Paolo | last3 = Froeschlé |first3=Christiane | title = The orbital evolution of the asteroid Eros and implications for collision with the Earth | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume = 380 | issue = 6576| pages = 689–691 | date = 1996-04-25 | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v380/n6576/abs/380689a0.html | doi = 10.1038/380689a0 | accessdate = 2011-02-12|bibcode = 1996Natur.380..689M }} {{cite journal | author=Thomas, P. The '''6AQ5'''<ref>[http://www.tubezone.net/pdf/6aq5el90.pdf Datasheet 6AQ5], General Electric'' Beam Pentode, June 1955, from tubezone.net</ref> ([[Mullard–Philips tube designation]] '''EL90''') is a miniature 7-pin (B7G) audio power output [[beam tetrode]] [[vacuum tube]] with ratings virtually identical to the [[6V6]] at 250V. It was commonly used as an output [[audio amplifier]] in tube TVs and radios. There are versions of this tube with extended ratings for industrial application which are designated as '''6AQ5A'''<ref>[http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/049/6/6AQ5A.pdf Datasheet 6AQ5A], ''RCA'' Beam Power Tube, Nov. 1958</ref> (with controlled heater warm-up characteristic), and '''6AQ5W/6005'''<ref>[http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/181/6/6005.pdf Datasheet 6005/6AQ5W], ''CSF'' Tétrode a faisceaux dirigé, March 1957 (in French)</ref> or '''6005W''' (shock and vibration resistant).
A [[Push–pull output|push–pull pair]] is capable of producing at least 10W audio output power in [[class-AB1 amplifier|class AB1]].
Other close or equivalent tube types are: '''6HG5''', '''6HR5''', '''6669''', '''6BM5''', '''N727''', '''CV1862''' and the Tesla '''6L31'''. The '''6CM6''',<ref>[http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/137/6/6CM6.pdf Datasheet 6CM6], ''Sylvania'' Beam Power Pentode, Jan. 1956</ref> like the Russian '''[[6P1P]]''' ('''6П1П'''),<ref>[http://frank.pocnet.net/sheets/113/6/6P1P.pdf Datasheet 6П1П], ''CCCP'' Output Beam Tetrode, 1970 (in Russian and English)</ref> while electrically equivalent (up to 250 V anode voltage), have a 9 pin (B9A) base. Another similar, but not identical, amplifier pentode with a miniature 9-Pin base (B9A), used in consumer electronics was the [[6M5]].

{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Action off Charles Island |partof=[[War of 1812]] |image=Frigate-essex-1799.jpg |image_size = 300px |caption=''USS Essex off Galapagos.'' |date=July 14, 1813 |place=off [[Bahia Bay|Banks' Bay]], [[Floreana Island|Charles Island]], [[Galapagos|Galapagos Archipelago]], [[Pacific Ocean]] |result= United States victory |combatant1={{flag|United States|1795}} |combatant2={{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] |commander1=[[File:US Naval Jack 15 stars.svg|23px]] [[David Porter (naval officer)|David Porter]] |commander2=[[File:Civil Ensign of the United Kingdom.svg|23px]] [[William Stavers]] |strength1=1 [[frigate]]
2 [[sloop-of-war|sloops-of-war]] |strength2=3 armed whaling brigs |casualties1=1 sloop-of-war damaged |casualties2=89 men captured, of which 48 were released on parole after the battle
3 brigs captured |notes= }} {{Campaignbox War of 1812: Naval}} The '''Action off Charles Island''' was a naval battle fought during the [[War of 1812]] in the summer of 1813 off [[Floreana Island|Charles Island]] in the [[Galapagos]]. An [[United States|American]] squadron of three vessels attacked three [[United Kingdom|British]] armed [[whaling|whalers]], and captured them. The engagement was notable for being one of the few to occur in the [[Pacific Ocean]] during the war and involved [[United States Marine]] [[Lieutenant]] [[John M. Gamble]], the first U.S. Marine to command an American warship.{{cite book |last=Hearn |first=G. Chester |title=Marines: An Illustrated History: the United States Marine Corps from 1775 to the 21st Century |year=2007 |publisher=MBI Publishing Company|page=21}} ==Background== In the War of 1812 between the United Kingdom and the United States, American [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] [[David Porter (naval officer)|David Porter]], in the thirty-six gun [[frigate]] {{USS|Essex|1799|6}}, led a fleet of armed vessels in the South Pacific in a [[commerce raiding]] operation. At the time of the action, ''Essex'' was accompanied by two smaller vessels, recently captured from the British and classified as [[sloops-of-war]] by Captain Porter. They were the 10-gun {{ship||Greenwich|1813|2}} of 338 tons [[Builder's Old Measurement|burthen]] and the 8-gun {{ship||Georgiana|1791 ship|2}} of 280 tons burthen. Porter had sent the rest of his fleet to [[Valparaiso]], Chile, to be sold while he and the remaining vessels patrolled for British [[whaler]]s between [[Tumbes, Peru|Tumbes]], [[Peru]] and the Galapagos.{{cite book |last=Gamble |first=M. John |title=The memorial of Lieut. Colonel J.M. Gamble, of the United States' Marine Corps, to Congress, 1828 |year=1828 |publisher= Geo. F. Hopkins & Son|pages=3–9}}{{cite web|url=http://www.leatherneckmagazine-digital.com/leatherneckmagazine/200805/?pg=4#pg4|title=Sound off|publisher=Leatherneck Magazine|page=2}}{{cite web|url=http://www.historynet.com/war-of-1812-commodore-david-porter-and-the-essex-in-the-south-pacific.htm|title=War of 1812: Commodore David Porter and the Essex in the South Pacific|publisher=HistoryNet.com|date=September 1, 2006}} Because Porter had entered the Pacific with no more than 350 American servicemen under his command, when he took prizes he could only place small [[skeleton crew]]s in most of his ships. ''Georgiana'' had a complement of forty-two men under Mr. Adams, the ''Essex''{{'}}s [[chaplain]], and ''Greenwich'' held only fourteen men under the command of Lieutenant Gamble, USMC. ==Action== [[File:John M. Gamble.jpg|200px|left|thumb|''John M. Gamble'']] There is some confusion as to the date of the battle; in later memoirs, Lieutenant Gamble recalled that it was fought on 12 or 13 July, while Captain Porter's memoir, and letters from Porter to Gamble, stated that it occurred on 14 July. Either way, at about 11:00 AM the Americans were sailing west from [[Tumbes, Peru]], off [[Banks Bay]] (Bahia de Bancos) in the Galapagos, when they sighted three sets of sails on the horizon. Commodore Porter signaled his ships to prepare for action and a chase began. At the time, the majority of British ships cruising in the South Pacific were whalers sailing under [[letter of marque|letters of marque]], legally permitting them to act as [[privateer]]s should the opportunity arise.All the vessels that Porter captured had crews whose size was more consistent with their being letters of marque than privateers. Vessels intending to engage in privateering had large crews, larger even than those of similarly-sized naval vessels, in order to be able to put prize crews on board their captures, while continuing to hunt for more prey. Porter himself suffered from having too few men to man adequately all his prizes. The first British vessel Porter captured was the [[brig]] {{ship||Charlton|1803 ship|2}} of ten guns. ''Charlton'' was sailing in the center of the three ships, and she surrendered to ''Essex'' without a fight as ''Greenwich'' and ''Georgiana'' went after {{ship||Seringapatam|1799 ship|2}}. ''Seringapatam'' had made several whaling and sealing voyages to the South Atlantic and this area since 1800. She had a 41-man crew under the command of Captain William Stavers and was armed with fourteen 9-pounder guns. On this voyage she had captured one American whaler on the way to the whaling grounds. When escape seemed unlikely, ''Seringapatam'' changed course and appeared to be sailing to engage ''Greenwich'' but the latter came to a halt and waited for ''Georgiana'' to come up and provide assistance. At this point, as four men were transferred from ''Georgiana'' to ''Greenwich'', Captain Stavers chose to break off the attack and flee. Lieutenant Gamble closed the distance between the two ships and he first demanded that the British surrender. But when the Americans came within pistol range, ''Seringapatam'' raised her colors and fired a powerful broadside. ''Greenwich'' immediately returned fire with small arms and cannon, and for several moments the two vessels exchanged fire. American fire proved to be more accurate, and after taking heavy damage the British struck their colors and ''Greenwich'' ceased her firing. Just as Lieutenant Gamble was preparing to board the enemy, ''Seringapatam'' attempted another escape. Gamble ordered his men to resume shooting at the sails of the British vessel and eventually brought her to a halt. Meanwhile, ''Essex'' had finished pursuing the small 8-gun {{ship||New Zealander|1808 ship|2}} and captured her without difficulty. Captain Porter then assisted in chasing down ''Seringapatam''. ==Aftermath== [[File:Commodore Porter off Nuku Hiva.gif|300px|right|thumb|''Captain Porter's fleet off Nuku Hiva in October of 1813.'']] American sources make no mention of casualties on either side, though ''Greenwich'' sustained some damage and ''Seringapatam'' was crippled. Porter took 89 prisoners in all, and the American ships were already filled with captives, so the Americans disarmed ''Charlton'', loaded her with 48 of the prisoners, and sent her to [[Rio de Janeiro]] as a [[cartel (ship)|cartel]] with the prisoners under parole with orders to surrender to the first American authority they encountered. ''Lloyd's List'' reported that ''Essex'' had captured ''Seringapatam'', Stavers, master; ''New Zealander'', Donneman, master; and ''Charlton'', Halcrow, master.[https://hdl.handle.net/2027/hvd.32044105232912?urlappend=%3Bseq=419 ''Lloyd's List'', 11 January 1814 - accessed 11 November 2013.] Captain Stavers, when asked to surrender his privateer's commission, revealed that though he had applied for a [[letter of marque]], he had not yet received one, but that it was probably waiting for him in Lima.{{refn|One had been issued on 12 December 1812.{{cite web|url=http://www.1812privateers.org/Great%20Britain/marque1793-1815.pdf|title=Letter of Marque, p.86 - accessed 25 July 2017.|publisher=|access-date=27 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161020052005/http://www.1812privateers.org/Great%20Britain/marque1793-1815.pdf|archive-date=20 October 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}|group=Note}} Captain Porter announced that Stavers would be taken to the United States and be tried as a pirate, and ordered him and his crew to be put in irons. They were given more freedom after some liberated American whalers told Porter that the British had treated them well during their time as prisoners aboard ''Seringapatam''. The American press declared ''Seringapatam'' to have been a formidable threat to American commerce in the Pacific, making Lieutenant Gamble famous, with the consequence that he received many letters of congratulations from naval officers. ''Seringapatam'' was found to have carried up to 30,000 dollars worth of armaments and provisions. Gamble was promoted to captain and died in 1836 as a [[lieutenant colonel]]. However, despite a petition to the U.S. Congress, he never received any prize money for the capture or his subsequent service.{{cite book |last=United States Senate |title=Index to the Miscellaneous Documents of the Senate of the United States|year=1871|page=84}} Following the engagement, Captain Porter made for [[Nuku Hiva]] in the [[Marquesas]] where he built America's first base in the Pacific and repaired his ships. He then sailed off, leaving ''Greenwich'', ''Seringapatam'', and another prize, {{ship||Sir Andrew Hammond|1800 ship|2}}, behind. It was after his departure that the [[Nuku Hiva Campaign#Seringnapatam Mutiny|''Seringapatam'' Mutiny]] occurred.{{cite web|url=http://www.historycentral.com/navy/MISC%202/seringapatam.html |title=USS Seringapatam |publisher=Navyhistory.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306060055/http://www.historycentral.com/navy/MISC%202/seringapatam.html |archivedate=2012-03-06 }} The mutineers and British prisoners-of-war recaptured ''Seringapatam'' and sailed her to Australia, from where she was returned to her owners. Gamble burned ''Greenwich'' before leaving Nuka Hiva in ''Sir Andrew Hammond''. ==See also== *[[Armed merchantmen]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=Note}} ==Citations== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Battles of the War of 1812}} [[Category:Naval battles of the War of 1812]] [[Category:Pacific Ocean]] [[Category:Galápagos Islands]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1813]] [[Category:July 1813 events]]

'''Beth Aala''' is a three-time award winning<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.documentary.org/project/made-boise|title=Made in Boise|publisher=}}</ref> American documentary filmmaker and film producer.<ref name="manillaTimes">{{cite news|url=https://www.pressreader.com/philippines/manila-times/20111228/281921654896609|via=PressReader.com|publisher=Manilla Times|title=Fil-Am Beth Aala wins third Emmy}}</ref>
==Life== Aala's parents emigrated from the Philippines to the United States,<ref name="manillaTimes"/> where she was born. She attended Elk Grove High School in Sacramento.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egcitizen.com/lifestyle/super-grads-making-history/article_1b6c8212-5e3a-56df-a3a5-1ca674f62fb2.html|title=Super Grads – Making History|publisher=}}</ref> Aala received a bachelor's degree from [[UC San Diego]] in both Visual Arts and Communication.<ref>http://www.philstar.com:8080/entertainment/738704/more-just-wiltime-1st-year-celebration</ref>
==Film career== Aala is best known for her 2013 film, ''[[Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon]],'' which she co-directed and produced with comedian [[Mike Myers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/reviews/film-review-supermensch-the-legend-of-shep-gordon-1201217356/|title=Film Review: ‘Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon’|first=Justin|last=Chang|date=10 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2016/09/28/films/shep-gordon-lives-life-like-movie/|title=Shep Gordon lives life like a movie - The Japan Times|publisher=}}</ref>
She was the codirector, with Susan Froemke and John Hoffman, of the film ''[[Rancher, Farmer, Fisherman]],'' which premiered at the [[Sundance film festival]] in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/rancher-farmer-fisherman-film-review-sundance-2017-966841|title='Rancher, Farmer, Fisherman': Film Review - Sundance 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/reviews/rancher-farmer-fisherman-sundance-film-review-1201966543/|title=Sundance Film Review: ‘Rancher, Farmer, Fisherman’|first=Dennis|last=Harvey|date=24 January 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
==Awards== In 2005, Aala won an [[Emmy Award]] for co-producing ''[[I Have Tourette's but Tourette's Doesn't Have Me]].''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/11/arts/television/children-persevering-in-the-face-of-tourettes.html|title=Children Persevering in the Face of Tourette's|publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> She also received Emmys for producing in the "Outstanding Children's Program" category in 2008 and 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/bios/beth-aala|title=Beth Aala - Television Academy|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2006, she won a [[Peabody Award]] for co-producing the film ''[[The Music in Me]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peabodyawards.com/award-profile/the-music-in-me|title=The Music in Me|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}

[[File:Plate Buwayhid.JPG|right|thumb|Painted, incised and glazed earthenware. Dated 10th century, [[Iran]]. New York Metropolitan Museum of Art]] [[File:Top Section of a Water Jug, late 12th-early 13th century.jpg|thumbnail|Top section of a water jug or ''habb''. Earthenware. Late 12th-early 13th century Iraq or Syria. [[Brooklyn Museum]].{{cite web|url=https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/99446|title=Brooklyn Museum|author=|date=|website=www.brooklynmuseum.org|accessdate=30 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180430234322/https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/99446|archivedate=30 April 2018|df=}}]] '''Earthenware''' is glazed or unglazed [[Vitrification#Ceramics|nonvitreous]] [[pottery]] ASTM C242 – 15. Standard Terminology Of Ceramic Whitewares And Related Products that has normally been fired below 1200°C.{{cite web|url=http://www.getty.edu/vow/AATFullDisplay?find=earthenware&logic=AND¬e=&english=N&prev_page=1&subjectid=300140803|title=Art & Architecture Thesaurus Full Record Display (Getty Research)|author=|date=|website=www.getty.edu|accessdate=30 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222053343/http://www.getty.edu/vow/AATFullDisplay?find=earthenware&logic=AND¬e=&english=N&prev_page=1&subjectid=300140803|archivedate=22 December 2017|df=}} [[Porcelain]], [[bone china]] and [[stoneware]], all fired at high enough temperatures to vitrify, are the main other important types of pottery. Earthenware comprises
most building bricks, nearly all European pottery up to the seventeenth century, most of the wares of Egypt, Persia and the near East; Greek, Roman and Mediterranean, and some of the Chinese; and the fine earthenware which forms the greater part of our tableware today.Dora Billington, ''The Technique of Pottery'', London: B.T.Batsford, 1962
[[Pit fired pottery|Pit fired earthenware]] dates back to as early as 29,000–25,000 [[Anno Domini|BC]],{{cite book|author1=David W. Richerson|author2=William Edward Lee|title=Modern Ceramic Engineering: Properties, Processing, and Use in Design, Third Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TSsR-orZAl4C|date=31 January 1992|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-8247-8634-2}}{{cite journal|last1=Rice|first1=Prudence M.|title=On the Origins of Pottery|journal=Journal of Archaeological Method and Theory|date=March 1999|volume=6|issue=1|pages=1-54|doi=10.1023/A:1022924709609}} and for millennia, only earthenware pottery was made, with stoneware gradually developing some 5,000 years ago, but then apparently disappearing for a few thousand years. Outside [[East Asia]], porcelain was manufactured only from the 18th century AD, and then initially as an expensive luxury. After it is fired, earthenware is opaque and non-vitreous,Combined Nomenclature of the [[European Union]] Published by the EC Commission in Luxembourg, 1987 soft and capable of being scratched with a knife. The [[Combined Nomenclature]] of the European Communities describes it as being made of selected [[clay]]s sometimes mixed with [[feldspar]]s and varying amounts of other minerals, and white or light-colored (i.e., slightly greyish, cream, or ivory). ==Characteristics== Generally, earthenware bodies exhibit higher [[Plasticity (physics)#Plasticity in soils and sand|plasticity]] than most whitewareAn industry term for ceramics including tableware and sanitary ware bodies and hence are easier to shape by [[RAM press]], [[Glossary of pottery terms#R|roller-head]] or [[potter's wheel]] than bone china or porcelain.Whitewares: Testing and Quality Control. W.Ryan and C.Radford. Institute of Ceramics & Pergamon. 1987.Pottery Science: Materials, Process And Products. Allen Dinsdale. Ellis Horwood. 1986. Due to its porosity, earthenware, with a water absorption of 5-8%, must be [[ceramic glaze|glazed]] to be watertight.Ceramics Glaze Technology. J. R. Taylor & A. C. Bull. Institute of Ceramics & Pergamon Press. 1986 Earthenware has lower [[Strength of materials|mechanical strength]] than bone china, porcelain or stoneware, and consequently articles are commonly made in thicker cross-section, although they are still more easily chipped. Darker-colored [[terracotta]] earthenware, typically orange or red due to a comparatively high content of [[iron oxide]], are widely used for flower pots, tiles and some decorative and oven ware. ==Production== [[File:Earthen Potter.jpg|thumb|[[Pottery]] using an electric rotor]] A general body formulation for contemporary earthenware is 25% [[kaolin]], 25% [[ball clay]], 35% [[quartz]] and 15% [[feldspar]].Dictionary of Ceramics, 3rd edition. A. E. Dodd & D. Murfin. Maney Publishing. 1994. [[File:Red terracotta flowerpots.jpg|thumb|left|Terracotta flower pots with terracotta tiles in the background]] Modern earthenware may be [[biscuit (pottery)|biscuit]] (or "bisque"){{cite book | title=The Materials and Methods of Sculpture | publisher=Courier Dover Publications | author=Rich, Jack C. | year=1988 | pages=49 | isbn=9780486257426}}{{cite web |url=http://ceramicartsdaily.org/firing-techniques/electric-kiln-firing/ten-basics-of-firing-electric-kilns/ |title=Ceramic Arts Daily – Ten Basics of Firing Electric Kilns |first= |last= |work=ceramicartsdaily.org |year=2012 |accessdate=16 April 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508074109/http://ceramicartsdaily.org/firing-techniques/electric-kiln-firing/ten-basics-of-firing-electric-kilns/ |archivedate=8 May 2012 |df= }} fired to temperatures between {{convert|1,000|to|1,150|C|F}} and [[glost firing|glost-fired]]{{cite book |last=Norton |first=F.H. |year=1960 |title=Ceramics an Illustrated Primer |publisher=Hanover House|pages= 74–79}} (or "glaze-fired")Frank and Janet Hamer, ''The Potter's Dictionary of Materials and Techniques'' to between {{convert|950|to|1,050|C|F}}, the usual practice in factories and some studio potteries. Some studio potters follow the reverse practice, with a low-temperature biscuit firing and a high-temperature glost firing. The firing schedule will be determined by the raw materials used and the desired characteristics of the finished ware. Historically, such high temperatures were unattainable in most cultures and periods until modern times, though [[Chinese ceramics]] were far ahead of other cultures in this respect. Earthenware can be produced at firing temperatures as low as {{convert|600|C|F}} and many clays will not fire successfully above about {{convert|1000|C|F}}. Much historical pottery was fired somewhere around {{convert|800|C|F}}, giving a wide margin of error where there was no precise way of measuring temperature, and very variable conditions within the kiln. After firing, most earthenware bodies will be colored white, buff or red. For red earthenware, the firing temperature affects the color of the clay body. Lower temperatures produce a typical red terracotta color; higher temperatures will make the clay brown or even black. Higher firing temperatures may cause earthenware to [[List of pottery terms#B|bloat]]. ==Types of earthenware== [[File:Chinese - Pair of Sculptures - Women on Horseback - Walters 492329.jpg|righjt|thumb|Chinese earthenware tomb sculpture.{{cite web|publisher= [[The Walters Art Museum]]|url= http://art.thewalters.org/detail/28463|title= Women on Horseback|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304050835/http://art.thewalters.org/detail/28463|archivedate= 2016-03-04|df= }} The Walters Art Museum.]] There are several types of earthenware, including: *[[Terracotta]]: a term used for a rather random group of types of objects, rather than being defined by technique *[[Tin-glazed pottery]], or [[Faience]] **[[Maiolica]] **[[Delftware]] *[[Lead-glazed earthenware]] *[[Redware]] (America) **[[Victorian majolica]] **[[Creamware]] *[[Lusterware]] with special iridescent glazes *[[Raku ware|Raku]] *[[Ironstone china]], on the border of earthenware and [[stoneware]] *[[Yellowware]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Rado, P. An Introduction to the Technology Of Pottery. 2nd edition. [[Pergamon Press]], 1988. * Ryan W. and Radford, C. Whitewares: Production, Testing And Quality Control. Pergamon Press, 1987. * Hamer, Frank and Janet. ''The Potter's Dictionary of Materials and Techniques.'' A & C Black Publishers Limited, London, England, Third Edition, 1991. {{ISBN|0-8122-3112-0}}. * "Petersons": Peterson, Susan, Peterson, Jan, ''The Craft and Art of Clay: A Complete Potter's Handbook'', 2003, Laurence King Publishing, {{ISBN|1856693546}}, 9781856693547, [https://books.google.com/books?id=PAZR-A9Ra6EC&pg=PA143 google books] ==External links== * [http://digicoll.library.wisc.edu/cgi-bin/DLDecArts/DLDecArts-idx?id=DLDecArts.RepManEarth Digital Version of "A Representation of the manufacturing of earthenware"] — 1827 text on the manufacture of earthenware * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070831123241/http://www.nfb.ca/objectifdocumentaire/index.php?mode=view&filmId=12&language=english&sort=title Short film on pottery making around the world] * [https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O21195/button/ Tin-glazed earthenware livery-button, ca 1651], [[Victoria and Albert Museum|Victoria & Albert museum]] [[Victoria and Albert Museum#Jewellery|jewellery collection]] {{Pottery}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Clay]] [[Category:Ceramic materials]] [[Category:Crockery]] [[Category:Pottery]] [[Category:Serving vessels]] [[Category:Cooking vessels]] [[Category:Food storage containers]]

{{short description|Japanese water deity}} [[File:Ebisu - color.jpg|thumb|upright|150px]] {{nihongo|'''Ebisu'''|恵比須, 恵比寿, 夷, 戎}}, also transliterated {{nihongo|'''Webisu'''|ゑびす||see [[historical kana orthography]]}} or called {{nihongo|'''Hiruko'''|蛭子}} or {{nihongo|'''Kotoshiro-nushi-no-kami'''|事代主神}}, is the [[Japanese mythology|Japanese]] god of fishermen and [[luck]]. He is one of the {{nihongo|[[Seven Gods of Fortune]]|七福神|Shichifukujin}}, and the only one of the seven to originate purely from Japan without any Hindu influence.
==Origins as Hiruko== In medieval times, Ebisu's origin came to be tied together with that of ''Hiruko'' - the first child of [[Izanagi]] and [[Izanami]], born without bones (or, in some stories, without arms and legs) due to his mother's transgression during the marriage ritual. Hiruko struggled to survive but, as he could not stand, he was cast into the sea in a boat of reeds before his third birthday.<ref name="Kojiki"> {{cite web | url = http://www.sacred-texts.com/shi/kojiki.htm | title = Kojiki | accessdate = 2006-09-09 | author = B.H. Chamberlain, translator | year = 1882 }}</ref> The story tells that Hiruko eventually washed ashore—possibly in {{nihongo|[[Ezo]]|蝦夷||ancient [[Hokkaidō]]}}—and was cared for by the [[Ainu people|Ainu]] {{nihongo|''Ebisu Saburo''|戎三郎}}. It is however believed that Ebisu first arose as a god among fishermen and that his origin as Hiruko was a much later conception, after the worship of him had spread to merchants and others. It is also theorized that he was originally a god known as "Kotoronushi no Mikoto", son of [[Ōkuninushi]].<ref>Encyclopedia Nipponica (Shogakukan): "えびす"</ref>
==Legend== [[Image:EbisuStationStatue6464.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Stature of Ebisu in front of [[Ebisu Station (Tokyo)|Ebisu Station]], [[Tokyo]]]] The weak child overcame many hardships, grew legs (and, presumably, the rest of his skeletal structure) at the age of three, and became the god Ebisu.{{citation needed|date=May 2011}} He remains slightly crippled and deaf, but mirthful and auspicious nonetheless (hence the title, "The laughing god"). He is often depicted wearing a tall hat—the {{nihongo|''Kazaori Eboshi''|風折烏帽子}}—holding a rod and a large [[red sea bream]] or [[Suzuki (fish)|sea bass]]. [[Jellyfish]] are also associated with the god and the [[fugu]] restaurants of Japan will often incorporate Ebisu in their motif.
==Cultural relevance== Ebisu's festival is celebrated on the twentieth day of the tenth month, ''[[Kannazuki]]'' (the month without gods). While the other myriad of members{{citation needed|date=May 2011}} of the Japanese pantheon gather at [[The Grand Shrine of Izumo]], Ebisu does not hear the summons and is thus still available for worship.
Ebisu is frequently paired with [[Daikokuten]], another of the seven gods of Fortune, in displays of the twin patrons by small shopkeepers. In some versions of the [[mythology|myth]] they are father and son (or master and apprentice). Also, these two are often joined by [[Fukurokuju]] as the "Three Gods of Good Fortune".
As a form of [[animal worship]]ping, Ebisu was often referred to marine [[megafauna]]s such as [[whales]] and [[whale shark]]s (hence being also called as "Ebisu-Shark") that bring mass of fish and protect fishermen.<ref>{{Cite book |author=村上健司 編著|title=日本妖怪大事典 |year=2005 |publisher=角川書店 |series=Kwai books |isbn=978-4-04-883926-6 |pages=182}}</ref><ref name="大藤1955">{{Cite book |author=大藤時彦他 |editor=民俗学研究所編|others=柳田國男 監修 |title=綜合日本民俗語彙 |year=1955 |publisher=平凡社 |volume=第2巻 |pages=763}}</ref>
Ebisu is depicted or parodied in a wide range of media, from artwork to costumed impersonations at local festivals and in commercial logos and advertisements. One of the most widely recognized product logos is in association with Yebisu beer, which was first brewed in 1890, and is currently brewed by [[Sapporo Brewery]].
Ebisu is the basis of the name of the clothing brand [[Evisu]].
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{one source|date=July 2016}} The '''FIG World Rankings''' is a system determining a list of the World's best gymnasts competing on the [[Artistic Gymnastics World Cup]]. A separate [[Rhythmic Gymnastics World Cup|World ranking]] system is also used for [[Rhythmic Gymnastics]].
Throughout the year, there are Challenge and Challenger World Cups for CII (all-around) and CIII (events) formats. A win on each event is a maximum of 50 points for a World Cup competition<ref>http://www.fig-gymnastics.com/publicdir/rules/files/art/ART%20CII%20WCup%20Rules%20%202013-2016%20(English)%2020160125_clean.pdf</ref> and 30 points for a World Challenge Cup competition.<ref>http://www.fig-gymnastics.com/publicdir/rules/files/art/GA_2016_CIII_WCup_Rules-e.pdf</ref>
== Final Women's Rankings (2014-2015 Season) ==
