revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}}
[[File:Global Country headquarters.JPG|thumb|A commercial building constructed using the principles and features of MVA]]
'''Maharishi Vastu Architecture''' (MVA) is a set of architectural and planning principles assembled by [[Maharishi Mahesh Yogi]] based on "ancient Sanskrit texts".<ref name=Argus>[http://download.tmnews.org/2005_08_05_RockIsArgus_ltr.pdf Welvaert, Brandy, Vedic homes seek better living through architecture", ''Rock Island Argus'', (August 5, 2005)]</ref><ref name=Spivack/> Maharishi Vastu Architecture is also called "Maharishi [[Sthapatya Veda]]", "Fortune-Creating" buildings and homes,<ref>[http://www.maharishivastu.org/ Official Web site, Maharishi Vastu Architecture]</ref> and "Maharishi Vedic architecture".<ref>[http://www.vedicarchitecture.org/ Maharishi Vedic Architecture]</ref>
MVA has strict rules governing the orientation and proportions of a building.<ref name=Toner>{{cite news|title=Houses that boost health and wealth|first=Niall |last=Toner|work=Sunday Times|location=London (UK)|date=July 22, 2007|page=10}}</ref> The most important factor is the entrance, which must be either due east or due north.<ref name=Toner/> The MVA architect also considers the slope and shape of the lot, exposure to the rising sun, location of nearby bodies of water and the other buildings or activities in the nearby environment.<ref>[http://download.tmnews.org/2005_07_AAAMag_ltr.pdf Egenes, Linda "Spotlight: Maharishi Vedic City", ''AAA Magazine'' (July 2005)]</ref> MVA emphasizes the use of natural or "green" building materials.<ref name=Argus/><ref name="ReferenceA"/>
MVA homes are marketed in the US by Maharishi Global Construction, LLC,<ref name=Hutchinson/> and by MVA Homes in the UK, both arms of the [[Transcendental Meditation movement]].<ref name=Clark/> Several communities around the world have been developed using MVA principles. The plans for [[#Peace Tower project|Peace Tower]], which would have been the world's tallest building, followed MVA specifications.
==Principles and effects== According to [[#Maharishi Global Construction|Maharishi Global Construction]] (MGC) in [[Fairfield, Iowa]], building a home according to the principles of MVA "connects the individual intelligence of the occupant of the house to the cosmic intelligence of the universe".<ref name=Argus/><ref name="ReferenceA">[http://download.tmnews.org/2005_09_TimesJourCont.pdf Times Journal of Construction and Design, In Accord With Nature, Niranjan Mudholkar, September 2009]</ref> Proponents of MVA say its basis is in the [[Vedas]], 5,000-year-old Sanskrit texts that assert a connection between human health and building materials, orientation to the movements of the sun and spatial relationships.<ref name=Spivack/><ref name="American Way"/> According to Lipman, Vedic architecture and [[feng shui]] have a common root, but MVA is more scientific, while feng shui has superstitious elements.<ref name=Gadd/> Lipman says that MVA is derived from "lost and misunderstood" principles, natural law, "whereby the entire universe is created: galaxies, planets, human beings" along with buildings and cities.<ref name=Carroll/>
Craig Pearson, Executive Vice President of [[Maharishi University of Management]] (MUM), claims that spending time in buildings that follow these principles makes one smarter.<ref name=Willdorf>{{cite journal|title=Karma and wrecking balls|first=Nina|last=Willdorf|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|location=Washington|date=June 2, 2000|volume=46|issue=39|page=A14}}</ref> Proponents claim that MVA homes have escaped wildfires that burned neighboring homes, and that businesses located in MVA office buildings have greater profit and lower absenteeism.<ref name=Toner/> Residents of MVA homes in [[Maharishi Vedic City, Iowa]] claim they felt vitality, calm and happiness when they moved into their Vedic houses. A mother claims that her boys are more orderly.<ref name=Balachandran/> Maharishi Mahesh Yogi has said, "Living in a proper vastu can eliminate 60 to 80 percent of the problems we encounter in life."<ref name=Balachandran>{{cite news|title=Vedic city: A city in the US follows building principles set in the Vedas|first=R. |last=Balachandran|date=September 9, 2001|work=The Week (Indian magazine)|location=Kerala, India}}</ref> Peter Warburton, Raja of England, says that the practice of Maharishi’s Vedic peace technologies is more powerful with Vastu buildings.<ref name=Warburton/> Yale University architecture professor [[Keller Easterling]] says that MVA is fueled by a desire to create outposts for broadcasting the [[Maharishi Effect]].<ref name=Easterling/>
Maharishi Sthapatya Veda is considered to be an element of the [[Maharishi Vedic Approach to Health]], and the main modality of MVAH for improving the immediate environment.<ref>{{Cite book| last1 = Schneider| first1 = Robert H. | last2 = Fields| first2 = Jeremy Z. | title = Total heart health : how to prevent and reverse heart disease with the maharishi vedic approach to health | year = 2006 | publisher = Basic Health Publications | location = Laguna Beach, CA | isbn = 978-1-59120-087-1 | pages=64, 193}}</ref>
===Siting=== Auspicious locations have water to the east or north.<ref name=Easterling/> If water is in an inauspicious location then it can be balanced with fountains on the north side.<ref name=Gadd/> Items in the nearby environment that generate electro-magnetic fields, such as high tension wires and microwave towers, are avoided.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The slope, if any, should be towards the east, and there should be no obstructions that block the sun's first rays.<ref name=Gadd/>
===Orientation=== [[File:Maharishi Centre for Educational Excellence, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, India..jpg|thumb|left|350px|MCEE School Campus at Bhopal, India, '''facing due east''']] The principles of orientation in Maharishi Sthapatya Veda are based on the position of the sun, considered by MVA to be the most powerful natural influence on Earth.<ref name=Argus/> Aligning a structure with the rising sun (facing east) is considered by MVA adherents to be auspicious for the building's inhabitants and to be "spiritually healthy."<ref name=Aspan>{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Aspan| first = Maria| title = Maharishi’s Minions Come to Wall Street| work = The New York Times| accessdate=December 17, 2009 |date = 2007-07-02| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/02/business/worldbusiness/02maharishi.html?_r=2}}</ref> According to the principles of MVA, the other three cardinal directions also have their corresponding influences. For example, homes with entrances facing west invite "poverty, lack of creativity and vitality,"<ref name="Kansas City Star">Canon, Scott, "Maharishi's followers have integrated into small Iowa town" ''Kansas City Star'', (September 28, 1999)</ref> and "anxiety, depression, bad luck and even criminal tendencies."<ref name="rickross.com">"Reclusive Guru's in Battle to Demolish Historic Dutch Monastery" ''Associated Press'', January 20, 1998</ref> According to the MVA official website, the north direction has the influence of prosperity and happiness and the south direction has the influence of negativity, problems and suffering.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Proper orientation is also said to increase business productivity.
===Placement=== When a house for a particular individual is being designed using MVA principles, the placement of the building and its rooms are carefully planned according to their intended usage and the influence of the sun as it moves throughout the day.<ref name=Argus/><ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="American Way">[http://download.tmnews.org/2005_07_22_AmericanWay_ltr.pdf Kissel, William "Home and Peace", ''American Way'' (July 15 2005)]</ref> Rooms are placed to "take in the sun's light as it passes overhead." Windows and skylights are also used to allow as much natural sunlight as possible to enter the building.<ref name=Argus/> An aspect of MVA called "Vastu Vidya" determines the places in the building that are used for generating and storing natural elements like fire and water, heating and plumbing.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Bathroom fixtures such as sinks and mirrors also have a particular placement according to MVA rules;<ref name=ArchImpressions/> Toilets have a particular direction depending on the Vastu design<ref name=Hutchinson>{{cite news|title=Wasting away in Maharishi-ville|first=Brian |last=Hutchinson|work=National Post|location=Don Mills, Ont.|date= February 22, 2003|page=B.1.Fro}}</ref> Kitchens and dining rooms should be on the east side, and offices on the west.<ref name=Toner/> commercial buildings are often designed as linear "bar buildings" to offer the most east-facing exposure.<ref name=Easterling/>
===Proportion=== MVA says that symmetry is orderly and helps to coordinate the various aspects of a structure, and that there is an ideal proportion for every room in a home or office. Also, the length, width and elevation of the building are calculated using the ancient Vedic mathematical formulas and requires a level of construction precision to one-eighth of an inch.<ref name=ArchImpressions/>
MVA planning and building takes into account the effects of the sun, moon, planets and stars, and also using the poles and the equator as reference points.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Its measurements and proportions are said to be calculated in reference to proportions of the human physiology and the cosmos, and in harmony with nature.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
===Features=== [[File:Maharishi Headquarters in Holland- cropped.jpg|thumb|A ''kalash'' atop a ''Brahmasthan'', with the flag of the [[Global Country of World Peace]], on the Maharishi's HQ in Vlodrop.]] One of the features of MVA design is the ''[[Brahmasthan]]'', whose literal translation is "establish wholeness". The ''Brahmasthan'' is a central space "lit by a skylight" that serves as a "silent core" and is "never walked on".<ref name="American Way"/><ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/transcendental-meditation-vedic-city-iowa/story?id=9218475 Berman, John and Burbank, Maggie, "Transcendental Meditation thrives in Iowa", ''ABC News'' (January 8 2010)]</ref> The ''Brahmastan'' is said to act as the "nucleus" or axis point for the structure like the nucleus of a cell or an atom.<ref name=Argus/><ref name="American Way"/>
Other features include a perimeter designation called a ''vastu'' fence. This boundary line may consist of shrubs or a metal, stone or wood fence. It is ideally about {{convert|30|ft|m}} away from the front and back of the building and eight feet away from the sides.<ref name=Toner/> Another feature is a "small, golden, roof ornament" or [[cupola]], called a ''[[Kalasha|kalash]]'', which one MVA architect says improves the connection between the residents and heaven.<ref name=Argus/><ref name=Hutchinson/> A defined plinth is another standard element.<ref name=Toner/> Color is also covered by MVA.<ref name=Paradkar>{{cite news|title=Before feng shui, there was vastu shastra; Indian science has formulas to align a home with nature Interiors, decor can be modified to best advantage|first=Bageshree |last=Paradkar|work=Toronto Star|date=March 10, 2005|page=J.06}}</ref>
====Ceremonies==== Three "special ceremonies" performed on "auspicious dates" are recommended by MVA. These include a ground breaking, which is described as digging a precise square hole while facing east, adding organic fertilizer and "sacred water" from India, and making statements of goodwill and success for the new construction. The second ceremony is the laying of the cornerstone and the third is moving-in.<ref name=ArchImpressions>Architectural Impressions, 2005 Edition, the Maharishi Vedic Center, Alan Sullivan</ref>
===Materials=== MVA buildings should not contain any iron or steel.<ref name=TMB91>{{cite news|title=Details of World's Most Advanced 'Sustainable' and 'Fortune-Creating' Building |volume=9 |issue=1 |date=September 2008 |url=http://www.tmbulletin.com/Volume9/TMBulletinV9I01.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717063738/http://www.tmbulletin.com/Volume9/TMBulletinV9I01.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-17 }}</ref> MVA emphasizes the use of natural or "green" building materials such as wood, bricks, adobe, rammed earth, clay, stucco and marble. Other natural fibers such as wood, paper, cotton and wool are used in the interior.<ref name=Argus/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> The use of natural materials, along with spacious plots and layouts, mean that MVA homes can be expensive, according to the MGC sales director, Eloise Raymond.<ref name=Gadd/>
==Architects== [[File:MUM campus and tower .JPG|thumb|Maharishi Tower of Invincibility, designed by Eike Hartmann]] Eike Hartmann is the Minister of Architecture for the [[Global Country of World Peace]],<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s7YZtZx6?url=http://www.invincibilitytrusts.org/ |title=Invincibility Trusts To Crown their Nations with Invincibility |publisher=invincibilitytrusts.org |url=http://www.invincibilitytrusts.org/ |archivedate=August 20, 2010 |accessdate=August 20, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref name=GFCNY>{{cite press release|title=HOW UNIFIED FIELD-BASED ARCHITECTURE CAN MAKE THE NATION INVINCIBLE|date=July 16, 2007|publisher=Global Financial Capital of New York|url=http://www.globalfinancialcapitalny.org/press/2007_07_16.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820010101/http://www.globalfinancialcapitalny.org/press/2007_07_16.html|dead-url=yes|archivedate=August 20, 2010}}</ref> the chair of the department of Maharishi Sthapatya Veda at Vedic University in the Netherlands,<ref>{{cite news|title=India Vedic city: A city in the US follows building principles set in the Vedas|date=September 9, 2001 |work=The Week|first= R. |last=Balachandran}}</ref> and designer of the Maharishi Tower of Invincibility on the campus of [[Maharishi University of Management]] USA. Jonathan Lipman is chief architect for [[#Maharishi Global Construction|Maharishi Global Construction]] (MGC)<ref name=Carroll>{{cite news|title=Turning a town eastward Guru's followers effect change in Iowa community|first=Dennis J. |last=Carroll| work=Boston Globe|date=May 4, 1999|page=A.3}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|volume=9|issue=1|date=September 2008|publisher=Maharishi Health Education Center|location=Lebanon|title=Details of World's Most Advanced 'Sustainable' and 'Fortune-Creating' Building: Complementary Vedic and 'Green' Principles}}</ref> and adjunct faculty member at Maharishi University of Management.<ref>{{cite news|title=Totally off the grid! MUM’s Sustainable Living Center — the "ultimate green building" |date=August 15, 2008 |work=Achievements |publisher=Development Office, Maharishi University of Management |url=http://www.mum.edu/achievements/2008_08_15.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s7OJGwWO?url=http://www.mum.edu/achievements/2008_08_15.html |archivedate=August 20, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mum.edu/admin/faculty.html |title=Administration: Faculty |publisher=MUM.edu |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s7MfuLMh?url=http://www.mum.edu/admin/faculty.html |accessdate=August 20, 2010 |archivedate=August 20, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Lipman reports having designed "hundreds of homes" and office buildings<ref name=Chediak>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/06/19/AR2005061900819.html |last=Chediak|first=Mark|title=Tower II planned with the Maharishi in mind|work=Washington Post|date=June 20, 2005}}</ref> including [[#Tower II|Tower II]], the largest MVA building to date. Henry Clark (deceased) was an architect at MGC<ref>{{cite news|title=Home builders toy with better designs as baby boomers age|first=RALPH |last=BIVINS|work=Houston Chronicle|date=January 26, 1997|page=34}}</ref><ref>[http://iagenweb.org/boards/jefferson/obituaries/index.cgi?read=63488 Henry Clark obituary]</ref> and the chief architect and planner for [[Maharishi Vedic City, Iowa]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Vedic Architecture In Harmony with Natural Law: Speakers |publisher=vedicarchitecture.org |url=http://conference.vedicarchitecture.org/speakers.html |accessdate=August 20, 2010 |archivedate=August 20, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s7Ouf32U?url=http://conference.vedicarchitecture.org/speakers.html |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref name=Kay/>
==Organizations==
===Maharishi Heaven on Earth Development Corp.=== {{Main|Maharishi Heaven on Earth Development}} The Maharishi Heaven on Earth Development Corp. (MHOED) announced in 1988 that it planned to build 50 "Maharishi Cities of Immortals" across the U.S. and Canada. The individual homes would be built using MVA specifications with non-toxic materials and natural ventilation.<ref name=SFC>{{cite news|title=30-Year Anniversary For the Maharishi|work=San Francisco Chronicle|date=August 17, 1989|page=A.12}}</ref> Its long-term goal is to "reconstruct the entire world".<ref name=Kay>{{cite news|title=Utopia? – Guru, backers have high hopes for heavenly housing concept|first=Marsha |last=Kay|work=The San Diego Union|date=December 25, 1988|page=F.1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Maharishi May Show Way To Heavenly Home|date=January 15, 1989|first=Eric |last=Zorn|work=Chicago Tribune|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-01-15/news/8902250480_1_maharishi-heaven-maharishi-mahesh-yogi-maharishi-school}}</ref>
===Maharishi Global Development Fund=== [[File:Clarion Hotel building in Hartford, Connecticut, 2010-02-20.jpg|thumb|upright|Clarion Hotel building in Hartford, Connecticut]] The Maharishi Global Development Fund (MGDF) was founded in 1997 in New York City. It had an initial capital of $430 million, which grew by hundreds of millions, and the stated capacity to handle multiple projects in several counties worth billions of dollars.<ref name=Taylor/> It has the goal of constructing buildings that reduce the world's problems.<ref name=Taylor/> It is also concerned with building cities and countries.<ref name=Easterling>{{Cite book| publisher = The MIT Press| isbn = 0-262-55065-2| last = Easterling| first = Keller|authorlink=Keller Easterling|title = Enduring Innocence: Global Architecture and Its Political Masquerades| date = 2007-10-31}}</ref> It was inaugurated on the top floor of the World Trade Center in 1997, and was a tenant on [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]].<ref name=Easterling/>
In 1995, the MGDF purchased a vacant hotel in Hartford, Connecticut, for $1.5 million. After being vacant for more than 15 years, the building sold in 2011 for $500,000.<ref>[http://www.courant.com/business/hc-constitution-plaza-hotel-0201-20110131,0,3985007.story] Long Vacant Hotel in Downtown Hartford Sells, Jan 31 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.hartfordbusiness.com/news16973.html] NY Buyer paid $500K for Hartford's empty Clarion, Greg Bordanaro, Feb 18 2011</ref> Yale University architecture professor [[Keller Easterling]] compares Maharishi Global Development Fund to "Arnold Palmer Golf Management", a developer of golf courses, adding that both "Arnold Palmer Golf Management" and "Transcendental Meditation" are registered trademarks and thus "ideologies and practices" that are regarded as "commercial products".<ref name=Easterling/> According to Easterling, both companies maintain a partial story which allows them to keep the "brand amnesiacally refreshed" and alter plans without explanation.<ref name="Easterling"/>
===Maharishi Global Construction=== The Maharishi Global Construction L.L.C. (MGC) markets and guides the construction of MVA buildings.<ref name=Taylor/><ref>{{cite news|title=Wasting away in Maharishi-ville|first=Brian |last=Hutchinson|work=National Post|location=Don Mills, Ont.|date=February 22, 2003|page=B.1.Fro}}</ref> Based in Fairfield, Iowa, Doug Greenfield is its volunteer president,<ref name=Paradkar/> Lipman is its chief architect,<ref name=Carroll/> Hartmann heads the legal department, and Clark is one of its architects.<ref name=Gale>{{cite web|publisher=Gale Business & Company Resource Center |title=Maharishi Global Construction L.L.C. |number=DC695654 |accessdate=August 16, 2010 |archivedate=August 18, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s3udAyW2?url=http://infotrac.galegroup.com/galenet/lapl?cause=http%3A%2F%2Fgalenet.galegroup.com%2Fservlet%2FBCRC%3Fvrsn%3Dunknown&ai2=CM&locID=lapl&srchtp=adv&cc=1&ab1=AND&ste=29&ab2=AND&tbst=tsVC&tab=1&ai3=CM&ai1=CM&RNN%25 |url=http://infotrac.galegroup.com/galenet/lapl?cause=http%3A%2F%2Fgalenet.galegroup.com%2Fservlet%2FBCRC%3Fvrsn%3Dunknown%26ai2%3DCM%26locID%3Dlapl%26srchtp%3Dadv%26cc%3D1%26ab1%3DAND%26ste%3D29%26ab2%3DAND%26tbst%3DtsVC%26tab%3D1%26ai3%3DCM%26ai1%3DCM%26RNN% |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It offers consulting services to architects and builders, but not architectural services.<ref>{{cite news|title=Peace of Mind|first=Esther |last=Hecht|work=Jerusalem Post|date=January 23, 1998|page=12}}</ref> It advised on $13 million in construction in 1999, and $90 million in 2003.<ref>{{cite news|title=WEEKEND JOURNAL; The Home Front -- details -- Beyond Bamboo: India's Feng Shui|first=Tatiana |last=Boncompagni|work=Wall Street Journal|date=October 3, 2003|page=W.12}}</ref> By 2003, it reported having built hundreds of Vastu homes in the US.<ref name=Gadd>{{cite news|title=Instant karma in a yoga home|first=Jane |last=Gadd|work=The Globe and Mail|location=Toronto, Ont.|date=December 5, 2003|page=G.8}}</ref> To reduce the cost of MVA homes, and to simplify compliance with the precise design constraints, MGC has begun to offer modular kits.<ref name=Gadd/> MGC also offers a "rectification service" to bring existing buildings closer to MVA standards.<ref name=Gadd/> Maharishi Global Construction L.L.C. officially dissolved in 2006.<ref>https://sos.iowa.gov/search/business/(S(rvf4g245tbs44jbtsbgl4kak))/filings.aspx</ref>
==Global Reconstruction== The Maharishi's Global Reconstruction Program for Permanent World Peace entails replacing the existing cities and buildings of the world with plans and structures that follow MVA principles. The project is estimated by the Global Country of World Peace (GCWP) Finance Minister to cost $300 trillion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://press-conference.globalgoodnews.com/archive/january/06-01-18.html |title=Maharishi Press Conference Highlights |publisher=globalgoodnews.com |accessdate=December 17, 2009}}</ref> A goal of the MGDF is to achieve "heaven on earth".<ref name=Taylor/> The Director of the Global Country of World Peace's [[Global Country of World Peace#Financial Capital|Financial Capital]], Paul Potter, said "we hope to be able to rebuild the whole world to be fortune-oriented buildings, to be heaven on earth".<ref name=Aspan/>
MVA principles were mandated in the platform of the Maharishi's "Invincible India Party" ([[Ajeya Bharat Party]]).<ref name=ZUBRZYCKI/><ref>{{cite news|title=The Maharishi at 80: Yogi in the sky with diamonds: A pyramid in India, the tallest building in the world, is among the projects planned by devotees.|first=Mian |last=Ridge|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=August 6, 1999|page=A.17}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=CONGRESS GETS JOLT IN MADHYA PRADESH|work= The Hindustan Times|location=New Delhi|date=November 5, 2008}}</ref> In 1998, it called for an overhaul of building laws to require all new buildings to comply with MVA.<ref name=ZUBRZYCKI>{{cite news|title=Transcendental election aim|first=JOHN |last=ZUBRZYCKI |work=South China Morning Post|location=Hong Kong|date= February 12, 1998|page=16}}</ref> One month after its 2001 founding, the [[Maharishi Vedic City, Iowa]], the council passed a resolution saying that city planning should be in accord with MVA principles.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s61YmJor?url=http://www.maharishivediccity.com/council/resolutions/06.html |archivedate=August 19, 2010 |accessdate=August 18, 2010 |title=Resolution No. 6: To create a Master Plan for Maharishi Vedic City incorporating all the knowledge of Veda and the Vedic literature to create a model city of peace, prosperity, happiness for the citizens, and ideal administration, and through the creation of this ideal city to bring the benefits of peace and prosperity to the State of Iowa, the United States and the world |publisher=MAHARISHI VEDIC CITY CITY COUNCIL |date=December 28, 2001 |url=http://www.maharishivediccity.com/council/resolutions/06.html |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
A 2000 document from the Maharishi Global Development Fund outlines a proposed method for cities to transition to Vastu buildings. The first phase is "controlling the expansion of the city by establishing a masterplan with parallel roads in east/west, north/south directions". The second phase is "construction of ideal villages and satellite towns around the city, free from pollution". The third is "starting to demolish congested areas in the city center, replacing them with beautiful gardens, parks and fountains". The fourth is "final stage of the expanded garden city, providing ideal living conditions, including a modern communication and transportation system".<ref name=Taylor>{{cite news|work=Dallas Business Journal|date=May 5, 2000|volume=23|issue=37|page=1|title=Maharishi eyes Colony project|first1=LISA Y.|last1=TAYLOR|first2=CHRISTINE |last2=PEREZ}}</ref>
The Maharishi said that "improperly oriented" building should be demolished, including the [[White House]] and the [[United Nations Headquarters|U.N. Building]].<ref name=Koppel/> He is quoted as saying that national leaders should vacate inauspicious buildings immediately, "as if an earthquake had hit them".<ref>{{cite news|title=Why the Cape city council is going south... |first=John |last=Yeld|date=August 29, 2005| url= http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=vn20050829110927675C207743 | page= 1 |work=Cape Argus}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=August 25, 2005 |title= Exhibits A and B |authorlink=John McCaslin|first=John |last=McCaslin|url=http://townhall.com/columnists/JohnMcCaslin/2005/08/25/exhibits_a_and_b|accessdate=August 1, 2010|publisher=townhall.com}}</ref><ref name=TMB>{{cite news|volume=5|issue=12|date=August 2005|work=TM Bulletin|publisher=Maharishi Health Education Center|location=Lebanon|title=Examine the Layout of All Government Buildings|url=http://www.tmbulletin.net/volume5/TMBulletinV5I12.htm|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.tmbulletin.net%2Fvolume5%2FTMBulletinV5I12.htm&date=2010-08-02|archivedate=August 2, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2001, he ordered numerous TM centers around the world to close due to inauspicious locations.<ref name=Piccalo>{{cite news|title=Good vibes; Maharishi Mahesh Yogi plans to promote world harmony from a soon-to-be-built 'palace' in L.A. An affluent area is preferred.|first=Gina|last=Piccalo|work=Los Angeles Times|date=August 2, 2003|page=E.1}}</ref> In 2005, the Maharishi told "everyone in the world to live and work in buildings constructed according to Sthapatya Veda or Vastu architecture".<ref name=Toner/> He said then that he would no longer talk or deal with any member of the TM community unless they lived in Vastu structures.<ref>{{cite web|title=16 November 2005 Press Conference Highlights: Opening Remarks |author=Maharishi Mahesh Yogi |publisher=Global Good News |date=November 16, 2005 |url=http://press-conference.globalgoodnews.com/archive/november/05.11.16.html |accessdate=August 15, 2010 |archivedate=August 16, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s1Qc0fqZ?url=http://press-conference.globalgoodnews.com/archive/november/05.11.16.html |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
He designated 2006 as the "Year of Reconstruction for the Whole World to be Heaven on Earth". The following year he included reconstruction in his seven-point plan for creating "invincibility for every nation". According to the Maharishi, "All the problems of the world will go away with our Global Reconstruction Programme".<ref>{{cite web|title=Maharishi's Achievements 1957–2008|url=http://www.mmyvv.com/machieve2.jsp|publisher=mmyvv.com|accessdate=August 1, 2010}}</ref> The elements of the world reconstruction program, as they appeared in movement newsletter in 2005, includes buildings such as:<ref name=TMB/> *"Maharishi Peace Palaces" *"Maharishi Vedic Universities" *"Maharishi Colleges and Schools" *"Maharishi Spas—Health and Rejuvenation Centers" *"Maharishi Fortune-Creating Office Buildings, Malls, and Hotels"
==Projects== [[File:Golden Gate Center building 2.JPG|thumb|The Golden Gate Center, a self described "Maharishi Sthapatya Veda Business Center", built in 1999 in [[Jefferson County, Iowa]], north of Fairfield.<ref>http://jefferson.iowaassessors.com/parcel.php?gid=7854</ref><ref>Golden Gate Center building {{Coord|41.0379|-91.9699|format=dms|scale:2000|name=Golden Gate Center building}}</ref>]] In the decade prior to 2005, about $250 million was spent on the construction of Maharishi Sthapatya Veda buildings, according to the ''[[Media in the Quad Cities#Print|Rock Island Argus]]''. About a third of that construction took place in the town of [[Fairfield, Iowa]].<ref name=Argus/>
According to a 2005 article in the [[American Airlines]] magazine, ''American Way'', "hundreds" of homes using MVA principles have been built across the U.S.A. including Wyoming, Iowa, Texas, Kentucky, Florida, North Carolina and Maryland.<ref name="American Way">''American Way'' July 15, 2005, Home and Peace, William Kissel</ref> The article says that "a growing legion of architects and scholars believes that by using the principles of Vedic architecture," good health and fortune can be incorporated into a home or building.<ref name="American Way"/> That same year, an article in ''[[Newsweek]]'' magazine reported that there had been $500 million in "new Vedic construction" during the prior ten-year period.<ref>{{cite news|last=Connant|first=Eve|title=Building on success|work=Newsweek|date=June 27, 2005|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2005/06/26/architecture-building-on-success.html}}</ref>
A 2008 ''Washington Post'' article reports that there are MVA buildings in at least 14 states in the US.<ref name=Spivack>{{cite news|work=Washington Post|title=Bricks Mortar and Serenity|first=Miranda|last=Spivack|date=September 12, 2008|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/12/11/AR2008121103497.html}}</ref>
===Buildings=== <!-- [[File:2000TowerOaksBldgbyRonBlunt MG 6475.jpg|thumb|Tower II building in Rockville, Maryland {{Deletable image-caption|date=May 2012}}]] -->
====Tower II==== MVA principles were used for a $72 million, {{convert|200000|sqft|m2|adj=on}}, nine-story office complex called "Tower II".<ref>Tower II {{Coord|39.0659|-77.1531|format=dms|name=Tower II|scale:2000}}</ref> Located at 2000 Towers Oaks Boulevard in [[Rockville, Maryland]], the structure has been named the "greenest building in Maryland", achieving a "platinum ranking" in the [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] (LEED), rating system.<ref name=Rojas>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/02/AR2009090201304.html Rojas, Rick, "Developer celebrates how 'green' is its building", ''Washington Post'' (September 3 2009)]</ref><ref>Ramstack, Tom, "Complex will be built with nature in mind", '' Washington Times'' (June 14, 2005)</ref> The "Fortune Creating Architectural/Vedic-designed office building" was developed by Lerner Enterprises and the Tower Companies and designed by Jonathan Lipman.<ref name="multihousingnews.com">[http://www.multihousingnews.com/2010/05/05/mhn-interview-with-jeffrey-s-abramson-vedic-architecture-can-change-the-way-people-feel-and-work-2/ MHN Online, Interview with Jeffrey S. Abrahmson, May 5, 2010]</ref> It was the subject of a Harvard Business School case study.<ref name="multihousingnews.com"/><ref>[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/harvard-business-school-studies-2000-tower-oaks-boulevard-90601854.html PR Newswire, Harvard Business School Study]</ref><ref>[http://cb.hbsp.harvard.edu/cb/product/210070-PDF-ENG Harvard Business School case study, paper]</ref> The building is one of a handful of MVA structures in the Washington, D.C., area. Jeffrey Abramson, a partner in the family-owned Tower Companies, is a long-time TM practitioner<ref>{{cite news|title=More Area Firms Paying Employees to Relax; Yoga, Meditation Seen As Health Care Boons|first=Annys |last=Shin|work=The Washington Post|date=March 3, 2005|page=T.12}}</ref> and the chairman of the board of trustees of [[Maharishi University of Management]]. According to Abrahamson "The human brain reacts to space" and by using appropriate proportions a working space can be designed to enhance productivity.<ref name=Spivack/>
====MAPI headquarters==== A {{convert|75000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} warehouse and office was built according to MVA principles in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado|Colorado Springs]], Colorado, for Maharishi Ayur-Ved Products International Inc. (MAPI).<ref name=Bean>{{cite news|title=Company in harmony with its surroundings/ New Springs headquarters mirrors philosophy of Indian health care|first=Joanna |last=Bean|work=The Gazette|location=Colorado Springs, Colo.|date=October 2, 1997|page=BUS.1}}</ref><ref>Maharishi Ayur-Ved Products International Inc {{Coord|38.8996|-104.8487|format=dms|name=Maharishi Ayur-Ved Products International Inc|scale:2000}}</ref> MAPI imports and distributes [[Maharishi Vedic Approach to Health|Maharishi Ayurveda]] herbal supplements. Every detail of the building, including the placement of the desks, is intentional.<ref name=Bean/> There are no [[Fluorescent lamp|fluorescent lights]], but windows and skylights are plentiful.<ref name=Bean/> When completed in 1997 at a cost of about $3 million, it was considered to be one of only 75 MVA buildings in the US.<ref name=Bean/>
====MERU==== [[File:20130723 MERU (Maharishi European Research University) in Vlodrop Holland - CC BY-NC-ND 1000x368.jpg|thumb|330px|left|The former residence of the Maharishi and Maharishi Vedic University in [[Vlodrop]], The Netherlands]] {{main|MERU, Holland}} The Maharishi Foundation purchased the {{convert|65|acre|m2|adj=on}} former St. Ludwig College Franciscan monastery at [[Vlodrop]] in the [[Netherlands]] in 1984.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aging monastery pits village against Maharishi movement Dutch residents are trying to stop meditation group's plans to raze building|first=MIKE|last=CORDER|work= Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=January 22, 1998|page=18}}</ref><ref>MERU, Vlodrop {{Coord|51.1571|6.1558|format=dms|scale:2000|name=MERU, Vlodrop}}</ref> In 1990, it became the Maharishi's headquarters and residence. Demolition of the monastery, which was declared a national monument, encountered resistance from local leaders. The Maharishi Foundation was enjoined from continuing and, despite lawsuits, it has not succeeded in getting rid of the large building.<ref name=Max>{{cite news|title=A Guru's Goals Still Center on Peace and Love|first=Arthur|last=Max|work=The Washington Post|date=February 19, 2006|page=D.01}}</ref> New buildings have been built around it. The main building is the Maharishi's palace. It is the largest wooden structure in the country and was built without using any nails,<ref>{{cite news|title=MY AUDIENCE WITH THE YOGI ; Whatever became of the Maharishi who bewitched The Beatles with his mystical teachings on meditation? DAVID JONES tracked him down to his bizarre private kingdom (complete with its own currency) where he conducted one of the most extraordinary interviews of his career|first=DAVID |last=JONES|work=Daily Mail|location=London (UK)|date=March 18, 2006|page=34}}</ref> at "vast expense".<ref name=Osborn>{{cite news|title=Real lives: Holy man of Maastricht: Since George Harrison’s death, the papers have been full of pictures of him with his Indian guru in the 60s. So what is the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi up to these days?|first=Andrew |last=Osborn |work=The Guardian |location=London, England|date=December 4, 2001|page=4}}</ref> About the building, the Maharishi is reported to have said that, "the walls of this celebrated building"..."in no way enclose his unbounded cosmic awareness".<ref name=GGN>{{cite press release|url=http://www.globalgoodnews.com/health-news-a.html?art=1181073654230287|title=Global Reconstruction will provide fortunate living conditions for everyone|date=June 5, 2007|publisher= Global Good News Service}}</ref> The building is a tourist attraction, though security is tight.<ref name=Osborn/> As of 2006, about 50 followers of the Maharishi live on the property in temporary huts.<ref name=Koppel>{{cite news|title=Outer Peace|first=Lily |last=Koppel|work=New York Times Magazine|date= October 8, 2006|page=24}}</ref><ref name=Max/> A 2007 press release says that 12 Raja palaces have been constructed on the site.<ref name=GGN/>
====Peace Tower project==== The Maharishi hired [[Minoru Yamasaki]], the architect of the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] towers, to design the world's tallest building.<ref name=Bey/> Called "The Centre of India" or the "Vedic Vishwa Prashasan",<ref>{{cite news|title=Higher, taller, richest?|work=Indian Express|location=Mumbai|date=January 6, 2010}}</ref> the 160-story, 2,222' (675.5m) tall building would have been considerably higher than the 1,483' [[Petronas Towers]], then the tallest building in the world.<ref name=Bey>{{cite news|title=Maharishi to build 2,222' building|first=LEE |last=BEY|work=Chicago Sun - Times|date=November 17, 1998|page=4}}</ref><ref name=Ridge/> The [[Gopuram|layered, pyramid-shaped building]] would be decorated ornately, with arches and columns,<ref name=BP/> like a Hindu<ref name=Braun/> or Vedic<ref>{{cite news|title=The Height of Ambition; Brazilian Envisions Tower as Soaring Statement of National Pride|first=Stephen |last=Buckley. |work=The Washington Post|date=August 30, 1999|page=A.13}}</ref> temple.<ref name=Romero/> The base would be 339 meters square, about 11.5 hectares.<ref>{{cite news|title=India Tower would dwarf others in race for world's tallest structure|work=Civil Engineering|location=New York|date=April 1999|volume=69|issue=4|page=16}}</ref> Priced at $2.5bn,<ref name=Bogler/> it would have been large enough to hold 60,000 or 100,000 meditators.<ref name=Ridge>{{cite news|title=The Maharishi at 80: Yogi in the sky with diamonds: A pyramid in India, the tallest building in the world, is among the projects planned by devotees|first=Mian |last=Ridge|work=The Vancouver Sun|date=August 6, 1999|page=A.17}}</ref><ref name=Braun/><ref name=MacKINNON>{{cite news|title=Spiritual devotees' towering ambition|first=IAN |last=MacKINNON|work=South China Morning Post|location=Hong Kong|date=November 6, 1998|page=12}}</ref> The foundation stone was laid on November 6, 1998, at the [[#Brahmasthan of India|Brahmasthan of India]].<ref name=MacKINNON/> The elaborate, three-hour ceremony was attended by dignitaries, including representatives from ten countries, and 2,000 local villagers.<ref name=BP>{{Cite news|title=India's transcendent building|work=The Bangkok Post|date=December 6, 1998|page=1}}</ref> No specific completion date was given.<ref name=BP/> As of 2010, the Indian tower was still described in news reports as an active project.<ref>{{cite news|work=Indian Express |date=January 6, 2010|title=Higher, taller, richest?|first=Bibek|last=Debroy}}</ref>
In May 1999, the Maharishi Global Development Fund announced that it would build a 1,630' (510m), 103-story tower in downtown [[Sao Paulo]], Brazil. The 60/40<ref name=Braun>{{cite news|title=La Jolla resident involved with maharishi in plans for world's tallest high-rise – Brazil project expected to cost $1.6 billion|first=Frank Dirceu|last=Braun|work=The San Diego Union - Tribune|date=August 7, 1999|page=A.12}}</ref> partnership with [[Brasilinvest]], a private development company, had a budget of £1.65 billion or $2bn.<ref>{{cite news|title=THE AMERICAS|first=Tom |last=Harvey|work=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=May 16, 1999|page=A.2}}</ref><ref name=Bellos/> The Maharishi Global Development Fund would provide $500 million directly and underwrite the rest of it.<ref name=FT1999>{{cite news|title=Sao Paulo awaits towering monument to Natural Law|work=Financial Times|date=August 25, 1999|page= 4}}</ref> Proponents said it would improve a run-down area near city hall, dubbed "cracktown", and restore civic pride. Skeptics questioned the need for the office and commercial space, the carrying capacity of the infrastructure, its location in a flood plain, the Maharishi's finances, and the overall viability of such a large project.<ref name=Romero>{{cite news|title=Another Entry for King of the Sky|first=Simon |last=Romero |work=New York Times|date=July 18, 1999|page=3.5}}</ref><ref name=FT1999/><ref>{{cite news|date=May 1, 2000|title=Nostalgia: A Generation of Gurus|first=EMILY |last1=MITCHELL|first2=Sol|last2=Biderman|work=Time}}</ref>
Its floor space, 1.3m sq m, would have been larger than the seven-building World Trade Center complex and almost twice as large as [[The Pentagon]].<ref name=Bogler>{{cite news|title=Sao Paulo awaits towering monument to Natural Law: Investment fund linked with maharishi says finance is ready to build world's tallest building in Brazil, but doubts remain|first1=Daniel|last1= Bogler|first2=John |last2=Barham|work=Financial Times|location=London (UK)|date=August 25, 1999|page=04}}</ref> When it was redesigned as a more conventional glass-sheathed skyscraper, one writer described it as a "giant [[saltcellar]]" with a hollow core.<ref name=Bellos>{{cite news|title=Cities racing for the sky: Sao Paulo tower in running for height crown|first=Alex |last=Bellos|work=The Guardian|date=June 11, 1999}}</ref> The project was slated to have a convention center, four hotels, a university, and apartments.<ref name=Bellos/> It would have had a monorail stop and underground parking for 25–100,000 cars.<ref name=Bellos/><ref name=Veash>{{cite news|title=Guru behind plan for Brazilian mega-tower|first=Nicole|last=Veash|work=The Scotsman|location=Edinburgh (UK)|date=November 15, 1999|page=8}}</ref> [[Mario Garnero]], head of Brasilinvest, said, "This isn't just a building, it's a city."<ref name=Bellos/> In October 1999, it was announced that the project had the support of the mayor and governor.<ref name=Bellos/> The land cost, $122 millions, would be split between investors and the city.<ref name=Braun/> It was to be paired with another project, the Transworld Complex, that would have a conference center, a golf course, and a theme park on {{convert|150|acre|km2}}.<ref name=Easterling/> Construction was predicted to begin January 2000.<ref name=Veash/> In November 2000, it was announced that the plan was being dropped due to government opposition.<ref name=Rich>{{cite news|title=Skyscraper Plan Dropped in Brazil|first=Jennifer|last=Rich|work=New York Times|date=October 27, 2000|page=W.1}}</ref>
The Peace Tower plan was moved to a {{convert|329|acre|km2|adj=on}} property in [[The Colony, Texas|The Colony]], Texas, a suburb of Dallas, renamed "Global Centre",<ref name=Krause>{{cite news|title=Maharishi Fund Puts 300 Acres in The Colony, Texas, Up for Sale|first=Kevin |last=Krause|work=Knight Ridder Tribune Business News. |date=March 17, 2003|page=1}}</ref> and rebudgeted at $3bn.<ref name=Campbell>{{cite news|title=Low flying aircraft threaten the world's tallest building|first=Duncan|last=Campbell|work=The Guardian|location=Manchester (UK)|date=October 25, 2000|page=2}}</ref><ref>The Colony property {{Coord|33.0735|-96.8639|format=dms|scale:2000|name=The Colony property}}</ref> The [[Federal Aviation Administration]] was concerned about the effect on air traffic and the project did not receive planning approval.<ref name=Krause/><ref name=Campbell/> The [[FBI]] investigated conflicts of interest allegations when the former mayor of the city was hired by the Maharishi's company.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guru wants to build Peace Palace: Arlington: City to decide if holistic institute can be built with tax-exempt bonds|first=Jeff |last=Mosier|work= Knight Ridder Tribune Business News. |date=November 22, 2006|page=1}}</ref>
Maharishi Development Project's Peter Swan announced plans in August 2000 for a tower at a site next to [[Alexandra, Gauteng|Alexandra]], Johannesburg, South Africa.<ref name=Campbell/> The 270-hectare property had been sold to the project by the [[University of the Witwatersrand]] after it found the soil was unsuitable for housing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Plans for 108-storey skyscraper in Jo'burg |date=August 2, 2000 |work=Independent Online |first=Anna |last=Cox |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/plans-for-108-storey-skyscraper-in-jo-burg-1.45830 |archivedate=December 2, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ufJTLDeo?url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/plans-for-108-storey-skyscraper-in-jo-burg-1.45830 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Towers were also proposed for each of the 24 [[time zone]]s.<ref name=Easterling/>
====MUM campus buildings==== [[Maharishi University of Management]] (MUM) is building new structures that follow MVA principles to replace 40 demolished buildings on their campus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mum.edu/reconstruction/demolition |title=Demolition|publisher=mum.edu|accessdate=December 17, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060831081146/http://www.mum.edu/reconstruction/demolition |archivedate = August 31, 2006}}</ref><ref name="Kelly"/><ref>[http://www.thehawkeye.com/Story/MUM-earthDay-042310 The Hawkeye, Sustainable Living Center is unique in US, April 26, 2010]</ref><ref>Heartland Connection, Greenest Building in America in Fairfield, Alex Halfmann, April 22, 2010 [http://www.radioiowa.com/2010/04/26/mahrishi-university-hopes-to-set-the-standard-for-green-buildings/]</ref><ref>Mormon lends skills to constructing self-sustaining, eco-friendly building, Kikari Loftus, June 10, 2010 [http://www.mormontimes.com/article/15044/Mormon-lends-skills-to-constructing-self-sustaining-eco-friendly-building]</ref> Most of the buildings on campus are now compliant with some or all MVA principles, including Dreier Building (the first MVA building on campus), Argiro Student Center, and two Peace Palaces.
The Sustainable Learning Center (SLC), designed by Lipman,<ref>{{cite press release|title=Maharishi University to Launch Renewable Energy System |date=July 22, 2010 |publisher=PRWeb |url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/press/renewable-energy-system,1393534.html}}</ref> is being built to the highest [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] standards.<ref name="Kelly">Radio Iowa, Maharishi University hopes to set the standard for “green” buildings, [http://www.radioiowa.com/2010/04/26/mahrishi-university-hopes-to-set-the-standard-for-green-buildings/Matt Kelly]</ref>
====Maharishi Peace Palaces==== [[File:Peace Palace Fairfield, IA.JPG|thumb|A Maharishi Peace Palace in [[Fairfield, Iowa]]]] {{Main|Maharishi Peace Palace}} In 2000, the Maharishi announced plans to build Peace Palaces in the 3,000 largest cities around the world.<ref name=Hamill>{{cite news|title=Sites for 'Maharishi Effect' (Welcome to Parma) Spread Across U.S.|first=Sean D. |last=Hamill|work=New York Times|date=February 22, 2008|page=A.14}}</ref> The buildings would be built with MVA principles and would house "dormitories, classrooms and shops".<ref name=Hamill/> As of 2007, Peace Palaces have been completed in at least four US locations, and land has been acquired in 52 other locations.<ref name=Aspan/>
====Other buildings==== The Spiritual Centre in [[Nasu District, Tochigi|Nasu]], the first MVA building in Japan, was designed like an ancient Japanese palace and is reported to be the country's largest wooden structure.<ref name=Balachandran/><ref>Spiritual Centre in Nasu, Japan {{Coord|37.0007|139.9367|format=dms|scale:2000 |name=Spiritual Centre in Nasu, Japan}}</ref> Comprehensive Blood & Cancer Center (CBCC), a {{convert|27000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} medical center, designed by Lipman, has been constructed in [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]], California.<ref name="American Way"/><ref>Comprehensive Blood & Cancer Center {{Coord|35.3613|-119.0745|format=dms|scale:2000|name=Comprehensive Blood & Cancer Center}}</ref> Ravi Patel, the founder of the CBCC, is a trustee of the Maharishi University of Management.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mum.edu/achievements/2009_09_05.html |date=September 5, 2009 |title=Maharishi College of Perfect Health Receives Founding Grant |work=Achievements |publisher=Development Office, Maharishi University of Management |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5s7UAgfas?url=http://www.mum.edu/achievements/2009_09_05.html |archivedate=August 20, 2010 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=July 3, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Cities and developments=== Maharishi Sthapatya Veda principles apply to communities and cities as well as individual buildings.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Communities should have ''Bramasthans'' at their centers, just like homes.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Ideal cities, according to plans drawn up by the Maharishi, are built in a grid pattern with gardens surrounding them.<ref name=Chocano/> Cities with bad arrangements include Paris and New York,<ref name=Chocano/> and it has been proposed that they be rebuilt on MVA standards.<ref name=Koppel/> Communities built according to MVA principles are called "Peace Colonies".<ref name=TMB91/><ref>{{cite press release|title=America's first Maharishi Peace Colony: A model, award-winning green development|publisher=Global Good News|date=26 June 2008|url=http://www.globalgoodnews.com/world-peace-a.html?art=121219719017183530}}</ref> According to the movement's "Maha Media" news portal, a "Maharishi Peace Colony" is a "community founded to help create invincibility for a nation, based on the principles of Maharishi's Vedic Science and its practical applications for living perfection in all areas of life—featuring homes and buildings for group practice of Yogic Flying—all built according to Vedic Architecture, Maharishi Sthapatya Veda."<ref>{{cite news|title=Thailand, Malaysia support world peace, invincibility |date=January 28, 2010 |url=http://mahamediaonline.com/newsDetails.jsp?Id=15145 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820115322/http://mahamediaonline.com/newsDetails.jsp?Id=15145 |archivedate=August 20, 2011 |accessdate=August 4, 2010 |work=Maha Media |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref>
====Maharishi Vedic City==== [[File:MaharishiVedicCity1.JPG|thumb|Homes in [[Maharishi Vedic City, Iowa]], where Maharishi Sthapatya Veda standards are mandated]] {{Main|Maharishi Vedic City, Iowa}} The city plan and buildings of Maharishi Vedic City (MVC) are based on Maharishi Sthapatya Veda.<ref>{{cite web|author=Craig Ridgley, Safire Internet Solutions, http://safire.net |url=http://www.maharishivediccity.com/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020803163047/http://www.maharishivediccity.com/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 3, 2002 |title=Maharishi Vedic City |publisher=Maharishi Vedic City |date= |accessdate=November 15, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref name="americanwaymag.com">{{cite journal|url=http://www.americanwaymag.com/maharishi-university-of-management-college-of-vedic-medicine-mahesh-yogi-fairfield |title=Home and Peace |work=American Way |first=William |last=Kissel |date=2005-07-15 |accessdate=November 15, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905155324/http://www.americanwaymag.com/maharishi-university-of-management-college-of-vedic-medicine-mahesh-yogi-fairfield |archivedate=September 5, 2009 |df= }}</ref> The Maharishi Vedic City is the first settlement to be built entirely on Vedic principles.<ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Lee| first = Jennifer 8.| title = In Many Ways, a New Iowa Town Looks to East| work = The New York Times| accessdate=February 8, 2010 |date = 2001-04-17| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/17/national/17IOWA.html?ex=1174190400&en=41eb2e441158fe53&ei=5070| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130516052734/http://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/17/national/17IOWA.html?ex=1174190400&en=41eb2e441158fe53&ei=5070| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 2013-05-16}} </ref> Easterling says that the city is an [[intentional community]] which epitomizes the idea that the personal and communal practice of TM brings a sense of well-being.<ref name=Easterling/> As the center of the [[Global Country of World Peace]], Easterling says that it reflects the GCWP's interest in achieving a "benign form of global sovereignty".<ref name=Easterling/>
====Other developments in and around Fairfield, Iowa==== [[File:Fairfield Business Park, Fairfield IA.JPG|thumb|Fairfield Business Park, an MVA building, in [[Jefferson County, Iowa|Jefferson County]], Iowa, north of Fairfield, built in 1998.<ref>[http://jefferson.iowaassessors.com/parcel.php?gid=7851 Description of building at Jefferson Co, Assessors web site]</ref><ref>Fairfield Business Park {{Coord|41.0639|-91.9716|format=dms|scale:2000|name=Fairfield Business Park}}</ref> ]] In addition to Maharishi Vedic City, there are several developments around Fairfield that are being built according to Maharishi Vastu design standards and the latest sustainability technologies. *'''Abundance Eco-Village''' is designed as an off-grid, and fully self-supporting development.<ref>{{cite news|date=July 1, 2009|title=Abundance EcoVillage: Residents say life off the grid is good|first=Amy |last=Greenfield|work=Radish magazine|url=http://radishmagazine.com/stories/display.cgi?prcss=display&id=446769}}</ref><ref>Abundance Eco-Village {{Coord|41.0416|-91.9600|format=dms|name=Abundance Eco-Village|scale:2000}}</ref> In March 2008, the development had five family dwellings;<ref name=DeWitte/> in early 2012, there were 14 homes built in three clusters.<ref>"Harmonious Living With Nature" by Mindy Kralicek, Iowa Outdoors, March/April 2012 p 52.</ref> Eco-Village has plans for a total of 30 homes.<ref name=DeWitte>{{cite news|title=Efficient living: Homes still look conventional|first=David |last=DeWitte |work=McClatchy - Tribune Business News |location=Washington|date=March 14, 2008}}</ref> In addition to relying on solar and wind for electricity, the development collects its own rainwater and grows organic food in common areas.<ref name=DeWitte/> *'''Cypress Villages''' is also designed with both MVA and sustainability principles.<ref>{{cite news|first=Paul|last=Schaefer|date=September 24, 2007|title=Going Beyond LEEDs, Beautifully, In Iowa|url=http://www.enn.com/business/spotlight/23347|work=Environmental News Network}}</ref><ref>Cypress Villages {{Coord|41.0501|-91.971|format=dms|name=Cypress Villages|scale:2000}}</ref> As of April 2010, it had 10 residents living in three houses.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cypress Villages defends its case for incorporation|first=LACEY|last=JACOBS |date=April 15, 2010|work=Fairfield Ledger|url=http://goldentrianglenewspapers.com/articles/2010/04/21/fairfield_daily_ledger/top_stories/doc4bc76ce34feea354144383.txt}}</ref> A petition to incorporate as a city, intended to allow the development to control zoning decisions, was rejected by a state board in May 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=State board dismisses Cypress Villages’ petition: Developer Dan Walker plans to see how the subdivision grows before he decides if he wants to seek incorporation again.|first=LACEY|last=JACOBS|date=May 13, 2010|work=Fairfield Ledger| url=http://www.goldentrianglenewspapers.com/articles/2010/05/17/fairfield_daily_ledger/top_stories/doc4bec5e49bc362945794302.txt}}</ref> *'''MUM North Campus Village''' is on the northern edge of the Maharishi University of Management campus, and is restricted to people connected to the university or the Super Radiance program.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vastu Homes: Frequently Asked Questions|url=http://www.vastuhomes.com/faq.asp|accessdate=July 27, 2010|publisher=Vastu Design and Construction, Inc.}}</ref><ref>MUM North Campus Village {{Coord| 41.0306|-91.9611|format=dms|name=MUM North Campus Village|scale:2000}}</ref>
====Heavenly Mountain==== Heavenly Mountain is a development near [[Boone, North Carolina|Boone]].<ref name=Mitchell/><ref>Heavenly Mountain {{Coord| 36.1744|-81.5825|format=dms|name=Heavenly Mountain|scale:5000}}</ref> The developers, Earl and David Kaplan, had purchased a total of {{convert|7000|acre|km2}} by 1993 and developed a portion of the land between 1996 and 1998.<ref name=Mitchell/><ref name="Watauga Democrat">[https://archive.is/20130209062406/http://www2.wataugademocrat.com/Community/story/Winning-bid-on-Heavenly-Mountain-hits-105M-id-006062 Watauga Democrat] "Winning Bid on Heavenly Mountain hits $10.5 million", Kellen Moore, September 2011. Retrieved September 2011.</ref> Several years later, Kaplan "sold most of the land for the Laurelmor development".<ref>[http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2011/sep/13/wsmet01-complex-up-for-sale-ar-1383933/ ''Wintson-Salem Journal''] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130126234231/http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2011/sep/13/wsmet01-complex-up-for-sale-ar-1383933/ |date=January 26, 2013 }} Heavenly Way complex up for sale, Sept 2011. Retrieved September 2011.</ref>
A part of the development became the Spiritual Center of America (SCA), a TM-related, non-profit, owned by Upper Blue Mountain Holdings LLC, which is reported to be controlled by Kaplan's extended family, took up {{convert|500|acre|km2}} and included a state-accredited university offering degrees in "consciousness-based studies".<ref name=Mitchell/><ref>[http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2011/sep/13/wsmet01-complex-up-for-sale-ar-1383933/ ''Winston-Salem Journal''] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130126234231/http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2011/sep/13/wsmet01-complex-up-for-sale-ar-1383933/ |date=January 26, 2013 }} Heavenly Way complex up for sale, September 2011. Retrieved September 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/743719005d9942b6a26e10d6f1bfde1d/NC--Meditation-Resort/ Winston Salem Journal, "Part of meditation center built by yogi's followers gets $10M auction bid from religious trust", September 15, 2011. Retrieved September 2011] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110924090200/http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/743719005d9942b6a26e10d6f1bfde1d/NC--Meditation-Resort/ |date=September 24, 2011 }}.</ref> SCA became the home for the Purusha (men) and Mother Divine (women) groups which practice the TM and [[TM-Sidhi]] programs in monastic settings. The groups had separate campuses, built to MVA and [[Underwriters Laboratories]] codes.<ref name=Treadwell>{{cite news|date=March 2, 2006 |title=What’s Going On at Heavenly Mountain?Is It Sold? Who Lives There Now? |first=Sally |last=Treadwell |url=http://www.highcountrypress.com/weekly/2006/03-02-06/n_heavenly.htm |work=High Country Press |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100802055238/http://www.highcountrypress.com/weekly/2006/03-02-06/n_heavenly.htm |archivedate=August 2, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref> SCA failed to gain an exemption from county taxes after a 2003 state Supreme Court ruling that the facility did not qualify as an "educational, scientific or charitable institution".<ref>[http://www.newsobserver.com/2011/09/15/1490793/part-of-nc-meditation-center-gets.html ''News-Observer''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926155613/http://www.newsobserver.com/2011/09/15/1490793/part-of-nc-meditation-center-gets.html |date=September 26, 2011 }} Part of NC meditation center gets $10 million at auction", September 15, 2011. Retrieved September 2011.</ref>
One thousand acres (4 km²) were set aside for development as a luxury resort by the for-profit Heavenly Mountain, with over a hundred lots for sale.<ref name=Mitchell/> A 2006 article in the ''High Country Press'' reported that a premium on the home prices helped to fund the SCA. The project was controversial in the area until Kaplan reached out to the community.<ref name=Treadwell/> However, Kaplan, a Purusha group member who left the group to marry, broke away from the movement in 2004 and decided to develop the land commercially.<ref name=Mitchell>{{cite news|title=PEAK OF LUXURY ; PLANNED RESORT LEADS TO ENTHUSIASM, WORRY; THE BUZZ: COMPANY KNOWN FOR RECORD SALES|first=Monte |last=Mitchell |work=Winston - Salem Journal|location=Winston-Salem, N.C.|date=February 28, 2006|page=1}}</ref> The SCA was evicted in 2006.<ref name=Treadwell/> Some home buyers were upset about being evicted and filed lawsuits and as of 2006, 44 condos and homes were still occupied.<ref name=Treadwell/>
=====Monastic communities===== According to a TM organization web site, the Mother Divine group had secured a residence and site for the Maharishi University of Enlightenment at the Heavenly Mountain location.<ref>[http://mue-motherdivinecapital.org/ Capital of Mother Divine for North America web site] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130054214/http://mue-motherdivinecapital.org/ |date=November 30, 2010 }}</ref> The facilities, called East Campus, were described as rooms and suites for about 200 females, along with dining and lecture halls, totaling almost {{convert|300000|sqft|m2}} of indoor space. The purchase price was estimated by [[Bevan Morris]], Prime Minister of the GWCP, to be one-seventh of the cost for new construction.<ref>[http://mue-motherdivinecapital.org/popups/bevan.html Bevan Morris, Prime Minister of the GWCP] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727102105/http://mue-motherdivinecapital.org/popups/bevan.html |date=July 27, 2011 }}</ref> The remaining 381 acres and 26 buildings of the Heavenly Mountain facility were sold for $6.35 million in 2011 to Blue Ridge Preservation Inc., who intend to work with the [[Art of Living Foundation]] and related groups.<ref name="Watauga Democrat"/><ref>Moore, Kellen (October 27, 2011) [https://archive.is/20130209081221/http://www2.wataugademocrat.com/News/story/-Developers-share-details-on-plans-for-Forest-Summit-id-006288 Developers share details on plans for Forest Summit] Watauga Democrat</ref><ref>[http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2011/oct/20/wsmain01-man-who-won-bidding-war-loses-spiritual-c-ar-1517704/ Winston Salem Journal] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130127050747/http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2011/oct/20/wsmain01-man-who-won-bidding-war-loses-spiritual-c-ar-1517704/ |date=January 27, 2013 }} Monte Mitchell, October 20, 2011. Retrieved October 2011.</ref>
The Maharishi Purusha Capital of the Western World is located on {{convert|170|acre|km2}} purchased by the [[Global Country of World Peace]] in 2009.<ref name=Pisciotta>{{cite news|title=Meditation Retreat Planned for Hampshire County |date=January 1, 2009 |first=Marla |last=Pisciotta |work=State Journal |url=http://statejournal.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=49132&catid=283&printview=1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716133109/http://statejournal.com/story.cfm?func=viewstory&storyid=49132&catid=283&printview=1 |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>Purusha Capital {{Coord|39.3883|-78.6264|format=dms|name=Purusha Capital|scale:2000}}</ref> This followed the Maharishi's call in 2007 to immediately establish a Purusha capital in the [[Blue Ridge Mountains]], according to the Purusha website.<ref name=Purusha>{{cite web|url=http://www.purushacapital.org/ |title=the Maharishi Purusha Capital of the Western World |publisher=purushacapital.org |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |archivedate=September 15, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5skiav9bN?url=http://www.purushacapital.org/ |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> It is in the [[Three Churches, West Virginia|Three Churches]] area of [[Hampshire County, West Virginia|Hampshire County]] near [[Romney, West Virginia|Romney]], West Virginia.<ref name=Pisciotta/> The property will be designated a Global Capital and will include a palace for the Maharaja and residences for the Raja of Invincible America and the Prime Minister.<ref>{{cite web|title=Purush Capital: Site Plan |url=http://www.purushacapital.org/site.html |archivedate=September 15, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5skjAFQhV?url=http://www.purushacapital.org/site.html |quote=The site plan includes a beautiful residence for Maharaja Adhiraj Raja Raam, the Raja of Invincible America and the Purusha Rajas at the top of the site, along with residences for the Purusha, Administrators, Computer Masters and National Representatives, as well as dining and meditation halls, fountains and gardens, a facility for residential courses including Transcendental Meditation Teacher Training program, organic greenhouses, extremely energy-efficient buildings, a 7-acre lake, walking trails and everything needed to make Purusha comfortable. |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> Accommodations for 150–200 people, including 120 professional meditators, are being constructed.<ref name=Pisciotta/> The Purusha website mentions the advantages of having as many as 800 "administrators of Global Raam Raj" so close to the nation's capital.<ref name=Purusha/> The buildings are planned to be built to Vastu and LEED standards.<ref name=Pisciotta/> The land cost $750,000 and the construction is budgeted to cost between $10 and $15 million.<ref name=Pisciotta/> Bob LoPinto, the Raja of Potomac Vedic America (regional director),<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.globalcountry.org.uk/news.php?f=uk20050829n_565654.htm&y=2005&cat=n |archivedate=June 15, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zSzVBxmh?url=http://www.globalcountry.org.uk/news.php?f=uk20050829n_565654.htm&y=2005&cat=n |title=His Highness Raja Bob LoPinto to Be Inaugurated as the Raja of Potomac Vedic America |publisher=Global Country of World Peace |year=2005 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> is overseeing the project.<ref name=Pisciotta/> A nearby but separate medical center or spa is also being considered.<ref name=Pisciotta/> An announcement on the Purusha Capital web site dated December 15, 2011 stated that "today we received all of our occupancy permits and so the Maharishi Purusha Capital of the Western World is now officially open!"<ref>[http://www.purushacapital.org/webcam.html "Construction Progress Reports"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127051629/http://www.purushacapital.org/webcam.html |date=January 27, 2012 }} Purusha Capital web site, December 15, 2011</ref>
====Maharishi Garden Village==== The Maharishi Garden Village is a 30-home settlement in [[Rendlesham]], Suffolk.<ref name=Clark>{{cite news|title=Transcendental HABITATION ; Om sweet om as the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi inspires an estate that's aligned with the rest of the universe. It's not as nutty as it sounds...|first=ROSS|last=CLARK|work=Mail on Sunday|location=London (UK)|date=March 25, 2007|page=8}}</ref><ref>Maharishi Garden Village {{Coord|52.1321|1.4159|format=dms|name=Maharishi Garden Village|type:landmark_scale:2000}}</ref> The movement had sought to purchase the {{convert|1000|acre|km2|adj=on}} former [[Bentwaters Air Force Base]] in 1995 for use as a campus but the deal, contingent on planning approval, fell through.<ref>{{cite news|title=Conservation battle looms over airfield site Property group in third attempt to develop Suffolk base|first=DAVID|last=FAIRHALL|work=The Guardian|location=London (UK)|date=December 30, 1996|page=4}}</ref> The movement's MVA Homes won approval for a development plan on the former base for 30 homes and 24 apartments.<ref name=Clark/> On January 12, 2008, the Maharishi's birthday, construction of a 12-story Maharishi Tower of Invincibility was inaugurated on the site.<ref>{{cite news|title=Towers to rise for Mahesh Yogi in 192 countries|work=The Hindustan Times|location=New Delhi|date=January 30, 2008}}</ref> In February 2008, MVA Homes submitted plans to build a £2 million, three-story, 33-bedroom Peace Palace in Rendlesham. It would be part of the 30-home, 24-apartment Maharishi Peace Colony. The plans were approved two months later, despite community concerns.<ref>{{cite news|title=Peace palace proposals prompt concern|date=March 14, 2008|work=The Evening Star|url=http://www.eveningstar.co.uk/news/peace_palace_proposals_prompt_concern_1_208066?ot=archant.PrintFriendlyPageLayout.ot}}</ref> The building will replace a center in Badingham that was used for 25 years.<ref>{{cite news|title=Suffolk to get a 'Peace Palace'|first=Richard |last=Smith|date=April 3, 2008|work=East Anglian Daily Times|url=http://www.eadt.co.uk/news/suffolk_to_get_a_peace_palace_1_188024}}</ref> As of 2010, 26 homes had been built and sold, with the remaining 6 to be built in 2011.<ref>[http://www.MVAhomes.co.uk/latestnews.html Latest News]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} at MVA Homes web site</ref>
====Brahmasthan of India==== According to the TM movement, the "auspicious" [[Brahmasthan]] (center point) of India is near [[Jabalpur]], [[Madhya Pradesh]].<ref>Brahmasthan of India {{Coord|23.5125|80.3172|format=dms|name=Brahmasthan of India|scale:5000}}</ref> The site has MVA housing for thousands of [[pandit]]s who perform [[Vedic chant]]s. The MVA design is said to amplify the power of their peace-promoting rituals.<ref name=Warburton>{{cite news|title=Maharishi’s Vedic Pandit World Peace Project|first=Peter|last= Warburton|work=Transcendental Meditation News|date=May 2001 |pages=3–5}}</ref> The project is overseen by Girish Varma, one of the Maharishi's nephews.<ref name=Warburton/> A series of "parliaments", including the "Maharishi Parliament of World Peace in the field of culture and religion", was held there in 2006, according to a movement press release.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mahamediaonline.com/newsDetails.jsp?Id=30273 |title=Culture and religion bringing perfection to life: Maharishi Mahesh Yogi |publisher=Maha Media |date=2010-07-04 |accessdate=July 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rdgKjv9Z?url=http://www.mahamediaonline.com/newsDetails.jsp?Id=30273 |archivedate=July 31, 2010 |df= }}</ref> A documentary filmmaker sneaked into the facility in 2009 and found, in the words of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', a "ghost town".<ref>[http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117942181.html?categoryid=31&cs=1 Simon, Alyssa "David Wants to Fly", ''Variety'' (February 14, 2010)]</ref> In 2010, a press release announced plans for new residential and visitor facilities, including 30 western-style suites.<ref>{{cite web|title=New facilities to offer opportunity to spend time at Brahmasthan |publisher=Maha Media |date=2010-04-21 |url=http://www.mahamediaonline.com/newsDetails.jsp?Id=23748 |accessdate=July 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rd5pzDdt?url=http://www.mahamediaonline.com/newsDetails.jsp?Id=23748 |archivedate=July 31, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
====Brahmasthan of America==== The Brahmasthan of America is near [[Smith Center, Kansas]], the [[geographic center of the contiguous United States]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Peace Palace receives go-ahead|first=ART |last=HOVEY|work=Lincoln Journal Star|location=Lincoln, Neb.|date=February 22, 2007|page=1}}</ref><ref>Brahmasthan of America {{Coord|39.9105|-98.7026|format=dms|name=Brahmasthan of America|scale:5000}}</ref> The County Commission initially passed a development moratorium to block the project but changed their decision after being threatened with a federal lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news|title=US county retracts from move against Maharishi Yogi’s project|publisher=PTI - The Press Trust of India Ltd|date=October 6, 2006}}</ref><ref name=Keen>{{cite news|work=USA Today |date=May 23, 2006 |page=03A|title=Maharishi meets the Bible Belt|last=Keen|first=Judy}}</ref> In regard to the local opposition, Eric Michener, the project coordinator for the GCWP, told a reporter, "I don't think we've run into this vibrant level of misunderstanding before".<ref>{{cite news|title=In Kansas, Peace And Disharmony; Maharishi's Project Alarms Farm Town|first=Carl |last=Manning|work=The Washington Post|date=June 11, 2006|page=D.01}}</ref> The group failed to receive an endorsement from the county commission when it sought a $38 million tax-exempt bond from the state.<ref name=Corn/> One palace is near completion and several others are in various stages of progress.<ref name=Corn/> In April 2010, a local newspaper reported that there was no activity on the site.<ref name=Corn>{{cite news|title=TM project in Smith County on hold |first=MIKE |last=CORN |url=http://www.hdnews.net/printstory/tm040710 |date=April 7, 2010 |work=The Hays Daily News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831171241/http://www.hdnews.net/printstory/tm040710 |archivedate=August 31, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
====Other developments==== Mandala Club was promoted in 2005 as a green development in [[Indian River County, Florida]], that would be designed with Vedic principles.<ref>{{cite news|title=S. Florida firms use green construction products: Sale of green construction products grows rapidly|first=Doreen|last=Hemlock|work=McClatchy - Tribune Business News|date=January 18, 2008}}</ref><ref>Manadala Club {{Coord|27.7093|-80.4068|format=dms|name=Manadala Club|scale:2000}}</ref> Three model homes were approved, out of a total of 90 planned, and the houses were estimated to cost $988,000 each. The {{convert|39|acre|m2|adj=on}} property went into foreclosure and was sold in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bank forecloses on Vero Beach's green housing development Mandala Club|first=Nadia|last=Vanderhoof |date=February 15, 2010|url=http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2010/feb/15/bank-forecloses-on-green-community-mandala-club/|work=TCPalm}}</ref>
==Reception== After hearing a presentation on MVA at the [[National Building Museum]] in 2005, a ''[[Washington Post]]'' reporter said that "non-adherents" may find the principles "eccentric, to say the least," as houses not facing east or north are said by MVA adherents to be "practically begging inauspicious forces to sweep in and wreak havoc." The reporter goes on to say that many architects would not "quibble" with other components of MVA such as "balance and symmetry", a vastu fence or wall and "solar influenced" placement of rooms in the home.<ref name=Turrentine>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/06/AR2005070600611.html Turrentine, Jeff , "Mind over mortar", ''Washington Post'' (July 7 2005)]</ref>
''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' travel writer Carina Chocano writes that Maharishi Vedic City "displays all the architectural characteristics of a new exurban development: gaudy, oversize construction that has no stylistic relation to its environment but instead vaguely alludes to a theme-park version, someplace sort of magical and far away."<ref name=Chocano>[http://travel.latimes.com/articles/la-tr-vedic10sep10?page=1 Chocano, Carina, "Meditation comes with creature comforts at Iowa's Maharishi University", ''Los Angeles Times'' (September 10, 2006)]</ref>
